content.question:
Given the following information, what would be the average groundspeed used to plan a climb from MSL (QNH 1013 hPa) to FL270?
CAS: 280 kt
ISA deviation: +5ºC
True Track: 045º
W/V
MSL: 275º(T)/10 kt
5000 ft: 280º(T)/20 kt
10000 ft: 300º(T)/20 kt
15000 ft: 310º(T)/45 kt
20000 ft: 310º(T)/45 kt
25000 ft: 330º(T)/55 kt
30000 ft: 330º(T)/55 kt

key_points: Some questions might give you a range of wind values and TAS values at various altitudes and a true track and ask for the average groundspeed
In these cases, the TAS and W/V to use on the Flight/Nav computer is as follows: For Climb problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude
For Descent problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude
learning.explanation: Some questions might give you a range of wind values and TAS values at various altitudes and a true track and ask for the average groundspeed. In these cases, the TAS and W/V to use on the Flight/Nav computer is as follows: For Climb problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude. For Descent problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude. The aircraft climbs from MSL (0 ft) to FL270. The 2/3 of the cruising altitude is at: 0 ft + [2/3 x (27 000)] ft = 18000 ft For the wind velocity at 18 000 ft then, we would usually have to interpolate 3/5ths of the way from 15 000 ft to 20 000 ft, but the winds are the same so no interpolation necessary. We can use the wind velocity 310º(T)/45 kt. For OAT, the ISA temperature at 18 000 ft is 15 - 2(18) = -21ºC, and the OAT is ISA +5ºC, so OAT = -16ºC To find the groundspeed, we first needs to calculate the TAS. (We have used a CRP-5 and the wind-down method here) On the computer side, in the air speed window, line up 18 000 ft with the OAT of -16ºC On the computer's inner scale, find the CAS of 280 kt, and read off the uncorrected TAS of 373 kt on the outer scale. As the TAS is over 300 kt, this needs to be corrected. In the COMP. CORR. window, calculate and apply the small correction in the direction of the arrow (only 0.7 divisions). Go back to the CAS of 280 kt on the inner scale, and read off the new TAS of 369 kt on the outer scale. The Groundspeed can be found using the wind side of the computer. Set wind direction 310ºT under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the centre point on the TAS of 369 kt * Mark the wind velocity 45 kt down from the centre point. Initially set the True Track 045°T under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would give 6º drift and a track of 051º, so reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 045º. This occurs at a heading of 038º with 7º Right drift. The groundspeed of this track is approximately 370 kt Therefore the average groundspeed for the climb is 370 kt, closest answer 371 kt. *Note: If your flight computer does not include high speeds, set 269 kt or 169 kt at the center point as TAS (TAS - 100 kt or TAS - 200 kt) and follow the rest of the procedure. At the final Ground Speed result you will need to add the 100 kt or 200 kt that you subtracted from TAS.

content.question:
Given the following information, calculate the drift and Wind Correction Angle WCA: Aircraft True Airspeed
TAS: 100 kt
Course: 180°T
Wind Velocity W/V T: 100/30

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 100º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG) & Ground Speed (GS), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 100º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 100 kt. Mark the wind velocity 30 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 180º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 17ºR drift and a track of 197º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 180º. This occurs at a heading of 163º with 17ºR (+) drift. WCA and drift are opposite to each other and of equal magnitude. A drift of 17ºR corresponds to a WCA of 17ºL (-). Triangle of Velocities: When creating the velocity triangle using the provided data, a right-angled triangle is established. This right angle corresponds to the angle formed by the W/V vector and the Ground Speed/True Track vector. If we denote θ as the angle between the Ground Speed/True Track vector and the True Airspeed/True Heading vector, the relationship can be expressed as follows: sin(θ) = Wind Velocity/True Airspeed = 30/100 = 0.3 ⇒ θ = 17.46º ≈ 17°. Since the True Airspeed/True Heading Vector is to the Left of the Ground Speed/True Track vector, we get that: Wind Correction Angle = 17° Left or -17°.

content.question: The distance between A and B is 105 NM. At a distance of 15 NM from A the aircraft is 3 NM right of course. To reach destination B, the heading should be altered by…

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (3/15) x 60 = 12º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (3 / (105 - 15)) x 60 = 2º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 12º + 2º = 14º L The aircraft is right off-track, the aircraft must fly left to regain track.

content.question: Over a period of couple of days it is observed that the duration of the daylight is longer and the sun tends to rise earlier. Time of the year is not close to the equinoxes. Where could this happen?

key_points: The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to its orbital elliptical path around the Sun at an angle of about 66
5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth's equator is 23
5o
learning.explanation: The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to its orbital elliptical path around the Sun at an angle of about 66.5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth's equator is 23.5o. The Sun will be exactly overhead 23.5o N in June, when "the northern hemisphere summer solstice" takes place and we have the longest day. Also, it will be overhead 23.5o S in December, when "the northern hemisphere winter solstice" will take place and we will have the longest night. The latitudes 23.5o N and 23.5o S are called the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn respectively and represent the highest latitudes where the Sun will be directly overhead. The tilt of the Earth's axis is responsible for the longer nights in winter and the longer days in summer. It also means that in extreme northern and southern latitudes, there will be times of the year in winter when the Sun does not rise and times in summer when it does not set. Between the solstices are the Equinoxes, when the Sun is passing over the Equator, where night and day are of equal length. The equinoxes are the times when the relative length of night and day and the elevation of the noon sun, known as the declination of the Sun, are changing at the greatest rate. If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year. The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic. At the Equator, the length of the day and night varies very little and then only due to the differences between the mean solar day (which is used for time keeping) and the apparent time kept by the Sun. Hence, at the Equator the sunrise will always be close to 0600 LMT and the sunset close to 1800 LMT. At the spring and autumn equinoxes, the time of sunrise and the time of sunset is approximately the same at all latitudes (within a few minutes of 0600 LMT and 1800 LMT respectively).

content.question: A definition of a Magnetic Track angle is:

options.A: The direction of a line referenced to the isogonic line to the Magnetic North pole. Compass North.
options.B: The direction of a line referenced to Magnetic North.
options.C: The direction of the longitudinal axis of an aircraft referenced to Magnetic North.
options.D: The direction of the longitudinal axis of an aircraft referenced to Compass North.

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

content.question: A pilot is flying VFR in VMC at 1 500 ft above ground, passing small separated villages. The pilot chose a church tower in such a village as a turning point for a new course. After completing the turn and flying towards the next waypoint, which is shown on the chart as a framework tower, the pilot is not able to find this tower at the expected time overhead. What is a likely reason for this navigation error?

options.A: The pilot changed course at a wrong village.
options.B: The vertical visibility was not sufficient to recognize the waypoints.
options.C: It is hard to recognize church towers in villages.
options.D: The framework tower is hidden behind buildings of the same height.

key_points: Visual navigation is the use of topographical maps to monitor or fix the aircraft's position
Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart

Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring, where the pilot must be able to visualise the terain and physical features from symbols on the map
learning.explanation: Visual navigation is the use of topographical maps to monitor or fix the aircraft's position. Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart. Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring, where the pilot must be able to visualise the terain and physical features from symbols on the map. Ground to map navigation, when the aircraft's position is uncertain, where the ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. The choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. The rule for choosing a ground feature is to find something as unique as possible, such as masts, railways, rivers, bridges, etc. Also, the map to ground technique is recommended to avoid confirmation bias, for instance spotting a tower on the ground and convincing yourself that it is the church tower you would dearly like it to be on the map. For this question, the pilot chose ground features (towers, villages) as turning points, which are identical with many others and can cause confusion to the pilot's flight monitoring. Also, VFR navigation at lower levels, as in our case 1500 ft above ground, restricts the view ahead and around by the next fold of high ground and objects may only appear when you are close to them and when they are not obscured by high ground. Probably, the pilot changed course at a wrong village, because of his/her low cruise altitude and not recommended ground features choice.

On the computer's inner scale, find the CAS of 137, and read off the TAS on the outer scale in that location, which is 162 kt. content.question: An aircraft flies from A to B, the ground distance is 78 NM. After 48 NM the pilot notices a cross-track error angle of 5° to the right. In order to directly reach point B, by using the “1 in-60” rule, the pilot should change the heading to the left by...

key_points: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 5°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track
To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B
For that, we need to find the distance off-track first
learning.explanation: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 5°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track. To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B. For that, we need to find the distance off-track first. We have been given the Track Angle Error (TKE) of 5º to the right. We can determine the distance off track by applying the following formula: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track 5º = (distance off track × 60) ÷ 48 distance off track = (5º x 48) ÷ 60 = 4 NM The correction to reach B will be: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 30 TKE = 8° ⇒ Turning 5º to the left will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 8° to the left will direct us to "B". 5° + 8° = 13° to the left to go direct to "B".

content.question:
Given:
Track= 355°
TAS = 190 kt
W/V 270°/25 kt
After 30 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 3.5 NM right of track and 4.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position.Calculate the actual wind.

key_points: The aircraft is not in the desired track because the actual wind is different from the forecasted wind
This exercise is asking us to determine the actual wind, and we will solve it using with the flight computer
To determine the actual wind we need the information related to actual path of aircraft over the ground, G/S and actual track and as well the TAS and actual heading information
learning.explanation: The aircraft is not in the desired track because the actual wind is different from the forecasted wind. This exercise is asking us to determine the actual wind, and we will solve it using with the flight computer. To determine the actual wind we need the information related to actual path of aircraft over the ground, G/S and actual track and as well the TAS and actual heading information. Based on the forecasted wind, and using the flight computer we can determine the aircraft planned heading and G/S. Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 190 kt. Mark the wind velocity 25 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 355º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 7ºR drift and a track of 362º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 355º. This occurs at a heading of 348º with 7ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 186 kt. At a ground speed of 186 kt, after 30 min of flight, the distance covered should be 93 NM. However, according to the question text, tha aircraft is 4.5 NM ahead = 97.5 NM. Therefore, the actual ground speed = 97.5 NM x 2 = 195 kt To determine the actual track over the ground, we will calculate the actual TKE and add it to the planned track. TEK = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TEK = ( 3,5 / (93 + 4,5) ) x 60 = 2ºR 2º right means that the actual track of the aircraft over the ground is 355º + 2º = 357º Knowing the GS 195 kt, TAS 190 kt, heading 348º and track 357º, it is possible to determine the actual wind using the flight computer by following the steps below: Determining winds with the flight computer: Set True Heading (348ºT) under "True Index" Place centre dot over TAS (190 kts) Mark the point where drift (9ºR) and GS (195 kt) meet. Rotate the wind computer until mark is below TAS. Check wind direction under "True Index" (253º) Count down from TAS to obtain wind speed (190 - 160 = 30 kt) Actual W/V = 253º / 30 kt

Rate of Climb is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the minimum vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Climb = Climb Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a climb gradient of 6% and a Groundspeed of: TAS - headwind component = 190 kt - 15 kt = 175 kt, the Rate of Climb will be: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = 6 % x 175 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 064 ft/min, which is very close to 1 100 ft/min.

content.question: What is the density altitude, given a pressure altitude of FL55 and a static air temperature of +33°C?

key_points: Note: This should not be a GNAV question
Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam
Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam
learning.explanation: Note: This should not be a GNAV question. Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam. Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam. Density altitude is a measure of the environmental air density, in comparison to where you would find that same density in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), so you end up with an altitude measurement. A high density altitude means low air density, and a low density altitude means high air density (what you would get at low-level). Density altitude can be calculated in 2 main ways, by flight computer or by mathematical calculation. By flight computer (CRP-5) it is relatively simple, in the "AIR SPEED" window, line up the pressure altitude with the OAT, and read off the density altitude in the "DENSITY ALTITUDE" window (x1000 ft). In this case, you get just under 9000 ft, but this is not the most accurate measurement in the world. We could show a picture in the annex, but flight computers are each very slightly different, so different answers could easily be found on different computers. By mathematical calculation, you take the pressure altitude, and adjust it for temperature by 120 ft per °C different from ISA. As high temperature is lower density, this means that higher than ISA temperature means a higher density altitude, and lower than ISA temperature means a lower density altitude. ISA temperature at 5500 ft (FL55) is 15 - 2(5.5) = 4°C, so with an OAT of +33°C, we are at ISA +29°C, meaning our density altitude is higher than our pressure altitude. The difference is 120 ft/°C x 29°C = 3480 ft, so the Density altitude is 5500 + 3480 = 8980 ft, closest answer 9000 ft

The ground speed is calculated by subtracting a headwind component or adding a tailwind component from TAS: Ground speed = TAS + tailwind component or Ground speed = TAS - headwind component Therefore, with a headwind, air distance is greater than ground distance.

learning.explanation: Mach number can be calculated using the following formula: M = TAS / LSS Where M stands Mach number and LSS is local speed of sound. The Local Speed of Sound is only dependent on absolute temperature and can be calculated as follows: LSS = 38.95 x √ K T(K) = ºC + 273 (1) Determine the OAT at FL410: ISA temperature at FL410 = -56.5ºC ISA dev = -12ºC Thus, OAT = - 56.5 - 12 = -68.5ºC (1) Convert ºC into K: K = -68.5ºC + 273 = 204.5 K (2) Calculate LSS: LSS = 38.95 x √204.5 = 557 kt (3) Determine the Mach number: TAS = ? kt LSS = 557 kt M = 0.86 0.86 = TAS / 557 kt = 479 kt Note: In an International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) atmosphere, the temperature declines by 2°C for every 1 000 ft of ascent until reaching the Tropopause, which occurs at an altitude of 36,000 feet. The True course in the flight log is 270°, the forecast wind is 045°T/15 kt and the TAS is 150 kt. After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 2 NM north of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position.
The track angle error TKE is..

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 045º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 150 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 045º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 150 kt. Mark the wind velocity 15 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 266º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 274º with 4ºL drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 160 kt. It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 GS = 160 kts Planned track distance flown = 160 x 15’ = 40 NM => This distance is based on the forecast wind, but the exercise states that the aircraft is 2.5 ahead of the dead reckoning position, actual position = 40 + 2.5 = 42.5 NM. TE = (2/42.5) x 60 = approx. 3º

content.question: An aircraft with a constant TAS of 180 kt, initially follows a magnetic track of 250°M, because of a drift 8°L. After turning, it follows a magnetic track of 340°M, because of a drift 8°R. What is the wind velocity and direction (T°), if magnetic variation is 10° East?

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least)
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Left, its heading is: 260°T + 8° = 268°T. When following a magnetic track of 340°M, its true track is: 340°M + 10°E = 350°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Right, its heading is: 350°T - 8° = 342°T. A method to assess the wind is to use the drift on different headings, known as multi-drift wind method: Place the centre dot over TAS 180 kt and put true heading 268°T under the True Index. Draw a line down the 8° left drift. Now put the next heading 342°T under the True Index and draw a line down the 8° right drift again. The point where the two drift lines intersect is the end of the wind vector. Rotate the disc until the intersection of the two drift lines is immediately under the centre dot on the 0° drift line. Read off the wind direction below the True Index as 305°T. And the wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot (180) and the value under the drift lines intersection (144): 180 kt - 144 kt = 36 kt. Thus, the wind velocity and direction (T°) is 305°/ 36 kt.

An aerodrome is located at Mean Sea Level and its traffic pattern altitude is at 2 000 ft. Given the following information, to reach downwind at the traffic pattern altitude, a 3° path descent must be initiated at (1)_____ prior to downwind, and it will last for (2)_____.

Average rate of descent for a 3° path: 750 ft/min

key_points: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60
So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o)
The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft, thus the height difference is 3 500 ft
learning.explanation: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60. So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o). The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft, thus the height difference is 3 500 ft. Therefore, the horizontal distance covered during the descent is: Distance to go (ft) = (3 500 ft x 60) / 3° = 70 000 ft or 70 000 ft / 6 080 = 11.51 NM, rounded 12 NM. The aircraft's average Rate of Descent is 750 ft/min, which means that it loses 750 ft in 1 min. learning.explanation: Deviation is called the difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north. The deviation experienced is specific to each aircraft and varies with heading and magnetic latitude. The variation with heading occurs because sometimes the resultant aircraft fields will oppose the Earth's field and sometimes reinforce them. Which heading this occurs on, depends on how the deviating fields are aligned within the aircraft. The variation with magnetic latitude occurs because the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field varies in strength depending where it is detected. At the magnetic equator, all the field is in the horizontal component, at the poles the horizontal component is weak to non-existent. Where the horizontal component is weak, the deviating forces are proportionally stronger and therefore the amount of deviation is greater near the poles and correspondingly less at the magnetic equator.

content.question: The distance between geodetic parallels of latitude on the surface of the WGS 84 ellipsoid…

key_points: The Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
You might come across the term "Geoid"
learning.explanation: The Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. You might come across the term "Geoid". In geodesy, a reference ellipsoid is a mathematically defined surface that approximates the geoid. Because of their relative simplicity, reference ellipsoids are used as a preferred surface on which geodetic network computations are performed and point coordinates such as latitude, longitude and elevation are defined. Modern navigation systems, like GPS, ude these reference systems and the most common of these is the World Geodetic System of 1984 or WGS 84, created by the United States military. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic latitude is the angle that a line drawn perpendicular to the surface through a point on a spheroid makes with the equatorial plane (plumb-line on the ellipsoid) and is other than the geocentric (earth centred) latitude. Despite the fact that, in general navigation, we assume that one degree of latitude along a meridian equals to 60 nm. In fact, using a WGS84 ellipsoid, one degree of latitude has a length of 59.7 nm (110.574 km) at the equator and increases progressively with increasing latitude up to 60.3 nm (111.694 km) at the poles.

content.question: Which statement about meridians is correct?

options.A: The plane of a meridian is parallel to the Equator.
options.B: All meridians are parallel to the Greenwich Meridian.
options.C: A meridian and its anti-meridian form a complete great circle.
options.D: A meridian is a complete great circle of 360°.

key_points: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere
All spheres have great circles
If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half
learning.explanation: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere. All spheres have great circles. If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half. A great circle has the same circumference, or outer boundary, and the same centre point as its sphere. The geometry of spheres is useful for mapping the Earth and other planets. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, but it maintains the general shape. All the meridians on Earth are parts great circles. Meridian and its anti meridian for a great circle. Meridians, including the prime meridian, are the north-south lines we use to help describe exactly where we are on the Earth. All these lines of longitude meet at the poles, cutting the Earth neatly in half. The Equator is another of the Earth's great circles. If you were to cut into the Earth right on its Equator, you'd have two equal halves: the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. The Equator is the only east-west line that is a great circle. All other parallels (lines of latitude) get smaller as you get near the poles. Great circles can be found on spheres as big as planets and as small as oranges. If you cut an orange exactly in half, the line you cut is the orange's great circle. And until you eat one or both halves, you have two equal hemispheres of the same orange. Great circles are also useful in planning routes. The shortest path between two points on the surface of a sphere is always a segment of a great circle. Plotting great circles comes in very handy for airplane pilots trying to fly the shortest distance between two points.

content.question: An aircraft following an approach procedure, which requires an approximate descent gradient of 6.6%, descends with an average groundspeed of 185 kt. What is the corresponding vertical speed (ft/min) required during the descent?

learning.explanation: Descent Gradient is the ratio of the loss of height for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage. Rate of Descent is the aircraft's vertical speed, the loss of height per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady descent, the vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Descent = Descent Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a descent gradient of 6.6% and a Groundspeed of 185 kt, the Rate of Descent will be: Rate of Descent (ft/min) = 6.6 % x 185 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 237 ft/min, which is very close to 1 220 ft/min.

content.question: In navigation we assume that the shape of earth is..

key_points: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round
The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator
The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there
learning.explanation: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round. The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator. The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there. This reduced gravity causes the land around the Equator to bulge outwards by approximately 21 km, while making the land at the poles appear flattened. The Earth is, therefore, an irregularly shaped ellipsoid, which is flattened at the poles and bulges at the Equator. This is slightly squished shape is called geoid. For most navigational purposes the Earth is assumed to be a perfect sphere (for simplicity).

A pilot intends to fly a route from A to B, covering a distance of 80 NM and departing at 12:15. The flight is planned with a heading of 235°. After 40 NM and at 12:27 the aircraft is crossing a rail line, which runs 90° to the flight track. At 12:37 the pilot should be 1 nm left of the track but s/he is actually 3 NM to the right. What Heading should s/he fly to reach her/his intended destination and what will be the ETA?

key_points: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed
The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM
Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt The off track error of 4 NM (1 NM + 3 NM) is recognized at 12:37
learning.explanation: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed. The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM. Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt The off track error of 4 NM (1 NM + 3 NM) is recognized at 12:37. We need to calculate the distance along track and the TKE (Track Angle Error) at this position. Time from A to railroad track (40 NM) ⇒ 12:27 - 12:15 = 12 min Time from railroad track to 4 NM off track position ⇒ 12:37 - 12:27 = 10 min Time from A to 4 NM off track position ⇒ 12 min + 10 min = 22 min If the aircraft's ground speed is 200 kt, in 22 minutes, it will cover: (200 kt x 22 min) ÷ 60 = 73 NM Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 73 TKE = 3° (approx.) If we alter our heading by 3.3° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: Distance to go = 80 NM - 73 NM = 7 NM TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 7 TKE = 34° (approx.) So turning 3° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 34° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 3° + 34° = 37º (approx.) would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the right, therefore we must fly 37º to the left. Track = 235º - 37º = 198º The aircraft is 80 NM – 73 NM = 7 NM away from the destination. At 200 kt, it will cover 7 NM in 2 minutes. The destination will be reached at 12:37 + 2 min = 12:39

content.question: The circumference of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

A pilot is planned to fly a track of 270°(T) towards ZVR VOR. At 10:20 UTC they plot their position and determine that they are on course. At 10:32 UTC, after having travelled for 60 NM, the pilot plots their position again and finds themselves 10 NM off-track towards the south. TAS: 280 kt
Forecast Wind: 150º/30 kt

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 150º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 150º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt. Mark the wind velocity 30 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 5ºR drift and a track of 275º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 265º with 5ºR drift. All this means is that, to counteract an expected drift of 5ºR, the aircraft flew a heading of 265º(T). However, after covering a distance of 60 NM, our track error angle is 10º left, meaning our track made good has been 260º (T) Calculating the difference between our heading and the track made good results in 5º to the left (265ºT to 260ºT). The average drift observed from 10:20 UTC to 10:32 UTC amounts to 5º to the left. Note: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading.

content.question:
When flying a VFR map-reading exercise, the pilot becomes lost because of isolated patches of fog hindering the ability to accurately pin-point his/her position. Which of the following should the pilot do in this situation ?
1. Maintain visual contact with the ground.
2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance.
3. Fly a series of expanding circles to find a suitable check point.
4. Look at the terrain for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, railway, river or coastline.
5. Read the map from map to ground.

key_points: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1
Note the time
learning.explanation: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1. Note the time. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. 3. Consider using any radio-navigation aids that may be available to give position information. 4. If short of fuel or near controlled airspace and not in contact with ATC, set 121.5 MHz and make a PAN call. 5. If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on route plan heading. Thus, statement 3 is incorrect. 6. Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position. 7. Compare the ground with your estimated position on the map. When the aircraft’s position is uncertain, ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. This is “ground to map”. Thus, statement 5 is incorrect. 8. Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as hills, valleys, lakes, wood, built-up areas, rivers, coastlines, motorways and railways. In all cases, maintain VMC and visual contact with the ground, note the fuel state and try to identify an area suitable for a precautionary landing.

content.question: The pilot of a piston-engined aeroplane, flying a VFR flight and approaching to the last turning point, realizes that he/she is both a few minutes behind schedule and low on fuel. What is the appropriate action that should be taken?

options.A: Make an emergency landing at the nearest suitable field.
options.B: Turn before the scheduled turning point and fly directly to the destination.
options.C: Fly to a lower altitude to increase the TAS and decrease the HWC.
options.D: Orbit and contact ATC to receive further instructions.

key_points: When a pilot realizes that he/she is behind schedule, most probably either a stronger headwind, or less tailwind or just headwind (in case calm wind was expected) is experienced
This situation will decrease the Groundspeed and as a consequence both the required total flight time and the total fuel consumption will increase
The fuel amount to cater for things that don't go to plan, such as stronger headwinds, re-routing, a flight level other than expected, is called "Contingency fuel"
learning.explanation: When a pilot realizes that he/she is behind schedule, most probably either a stronger headwind, or less tailwind or just headwind (in case calm wind was expected) is experienced. This situation will decrease the Groundspeed and as a consequence both the required total flight time and the total fuel consumption will increase. The fuel amount to cater for things that don't go to plan, such as stronger headwinds, re-routing, a flight level other than expected, is called "Contingency fuel". Also, any aircraft must be landed with at least the Final Reserve Fuel in its tanks. If it looks like that it will land with less than Final Reserve Fuel, EU OPS says that the pilot must declare an emergency. But, for this question the Contingency fuel may not be sufficient and so as to avoid any consumption of the Final Reserve Fuel while being still on the air before landing, the best action is to reduce, as much as possible, the remaining ground distance and flight time until the destination, by turning before the scheduled turning point and flying directly to the destination, provided that the ATC is informed of the pilot's intentions accordingly and no safety issues emerge. An emergency landing at the nearest suitable field may pose at risk both the passengers and the aircraft and would be recommended in case the remaining fuel was not sufficient to reach at any other suitable airfield. Flying to a lower altitude would decrease the TAS and the Groundspeed, thus the required flight time and fuel to destination would increase. Any orbit would further increase the flight time and total fuel consumption until destination. Further instructions from the ATC should be asked while continuing towards the destination without wasting flight time.

content.question: A pilot has planned a navigation flight for daytime hours, but flies it at night. What is the most significant hazard of this flight?

options.C: Difficulty in identifying landmarks and reference points.
options.D: Increased risk associated with optical obstacles such as tail masts at night compared to daytime.

key_points: While planning a VFR navigation flight for daytime, natural landmarks such as roads, rivers, and towns might be selected to be used as visual cues
However, at night the visibility of these features is reduced or even impossible, making it challenging for the pilots to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references

The limited visibility at night might cause difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points to verify the position of the aircraft and cross-check the aircraft track, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost
learning.explanation: While planning a VFR navigation flight for daytime, natural landmarks such as roads, rivers, and towns might be selected to be used as visual cues. However, at night the visibility of these features is reduced or even impossible, making it challenging for the pilots to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references. The limited visibility at night might cause difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points to verify the position of the aircraft and cross-check the aircraft track, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. Therefore, the difficulty to identify the navigation features at night is the most significant hazard because it directly affects the pilot's ability to navigate safely and accurately during the flight. Tall obstacles at night are properly marked, and can be managed with proper planning, preparation, and adherence to procedures designed for night flying. Note: The difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points is caused due to limited visibility, so the choice 'Limited visibility and off-navigation challenges.' is a hazard but the most significant aspect of limited visibility is the inability to identify the landmarks. This is why the choice 'Difficulty in identifying landmarks and reference points.' is chosen the correct one.

content.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints. What should you do?

options.A: Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure.
options.D: Proceed and turn at the next checkpoint based on time.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: There exist two akin questions within the database

In cases where the pilot cannot verify their position, it is advised to initiate the "unsure of position" procedure
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: There exist two akin questions within the database. Question 615066 specifies the pilot being lost. In cases where the pilot cannot verify their position, it is advised to initiate the "unsure of position" procedure. Should the pilot be unable to ascertain their position even after, they should proceed with the "lost procedure." Nevertheless, if the pilot possesses knowledge of their location, they should proceed according to the original plan. In this case, given that the flight is scheduled to take place over a snowy region lacking ground landmarks, the pilot needs to exercise meticulous care in adhering to the predetermined headings. It's crucial to uphold situational awareness throughout the entire flight duration, consistently assess the flight's progress, and particularly when approaching a designated turning point devoid of visible ground references, make the turn toward the subsequent waypoint according to the pre-calculated time established during the planning phase. Unlike question 615066, this particular question does not indicate that the pilot is disoriented or lost. Consequently, there is no justification for initiating the "lost procedure". content.question: A pilot flying a VFR flight got lost while in contact with ATC and with enough fuel in tanks. What are the recommended actions in this case?

options.A: Note the actual time and ask ATC for help.
options.B: Make an urgency call (PAN PAN) on frequency 121.5 MHz.

key_points: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1
Note the actual time
learning.explanation: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1. Note the actual time. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. If there is no contact on that frequency or there is no frequency selected, change to 121.500 MHz, make a PAN call and select 7700 with ALT on the transponder, if fitted. 3. Consider using any radio-navigation aids that may be available to give position information. 4. If short of fuel or near controlled airspace and not in contact with ATC, set 121.5 MHz and make a PAN call. 5. If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on route plan heading. 6. Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position. 7. Compare the ground with your estimated position on the map. 8. Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as hills, valleys, lakes, wood, built-up areas, rivers, coastlines, motorways and railways.

content.question: A VFR flight is planned with a chart whose scale is 1:500 000. The ground feature which should be used for orientation is/are:

key_points: “A small hill
” Incorrect
When looking down from the aircraft, the ground appears to flatten
learning.explanation: “A small hill.” Incorrect. When looking down from the aircraft, the ground appears to flatten. A small hill is not easily distinguished from the remaining terrain. “Towers widely spread.” Incorrect This is not a suitable checkpoint. For instance, if the pilot selects the first tower as a visual marking, it may be confused with the remaining towers. If the towers have similar features this is probable. “Small roads crossing.” Correct. content.question: What will be the risk if a night VFR flight navigates out of the studied route?

options.D: The obstacles seem to be closer.

key_points: It is very important that the pilot performs a full preflight for a night flight
The temptation to skip or skim over steps in the preflight is much higher at night when you are juggling a flashlight along with the ladder and fuel cap
Still, remain disciplined and avoid cutting corners
learning.explanation: It is very important that the pilot performs a full preflight for a night flight. The temptation to skip or skim over steps in the preflight is much higher at night when you are juggling a flashlight along with the ladder and fuel cap. Still, remain disciplined and avoid cutting corners. It is also paramount that you familiarize yourself with night flying illusions. Night flying illusions are common and can be deadly if not recognized and compensated for quickly. Learn how to identify and recover from all the tricks your senses can play on you in the dark. The pilot must study the obstacles in the area over which he/she plans to fly, but also the obstacles around the intended route in case, for example, a deviation is necessary. "The airport can not be identified due to lighting." Incorrect - The airport facilities and runways will be lighted, making it possible for the pilot to identify it. "The obstacles marked with red light due to red wavelength." Incorrect – Such lights are used to warn the pilots for the presence of obstacles.

content.question: An aircraft is making a VFR cross-country flight at low level. The flight involves at least four visual checkpoints on the route. What is the most suitable type of checkpoint?

options.A: Fly as low as possible and select aerodromes that are active for parachuting and gliding.
options.B: If flying over a wet, lowland area, choose small lakes rather than large ones.
options.C: Look for distinctive features such as a railway line to lead into a checkpoint.
options.D: Choose large, built-up areas that can be seen easily from low level.

key_points: Checkpoints are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air
PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance
Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice
learning.explanation: Checkpoints are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance. Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice. Ground features on or close to track are preferred. Here's a list of some of the easiest points to spot from the air: Airports with Paved Runways: The taxiways and runways of nearby airports are easy to spot due to large clearings. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower?

content.question: A pilot is flying a VFR flight from A (50ºN, 010ºE) to B (51ºN, 010ºE). They have plotted the flight as a straight line on their chart. Which of the following visual landmarks is suitable for determining their lateral deviation from the track?

options.A: Four large masts on the horizon, one at approximately each of the cardinal points from the aircraft (North, South, East and West).
options.B: A large highway crossing the track in the East/West direction.
options.C: A large city, 15 nm West of the planned track.
options.D: A large waterway running from North to South along the track.

These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air. When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude. They should have unique features that differentiate them from other nearby object. Prominence: Checkpoints should stand out from their surroundings. They could be easily recognizable structures, geographical features, or landmarks that can be seen from a distance. Contrast with Terrain: Checkpoints should exhibit visual contrast with the surrounding terrain. This contrast can result from differences in color, texture, shape, or elevation. Proximity to Intended Path: Optimal VFR checkpoints lie directly on or in close proximity to the planned flight track, enhancing navigation accuracy. Planned Altitude Consideration: When selecting checkpoints, the intended cruising altitude must be considered. Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration. A tall rectangular building is a suitable ground feature for VFR navigation, because it is has the following characteristics: It has enough vertical extent to be identified from a considerable distance and altitude, and it has a distinctive shape that makes it easily recognizable. It is prominent and unique, standing out against the surrounding terrain. It makes contrast with its surroundings due to differences in shape and elevation.

learning.explanation: Some of the problems faced by a pilot during VFR navigation at lower levels are the following: The horizon may be obscured by high ground, so attitude flying is difficult. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. key_points: FLAT LIGHT / PARTIAL WHITEOUT "An atmospheric optical phenomenon of the polar regions in which the observer appears to be engulfed in a uniformly white glow
Neither shadows, horizon nor clouds are discernible; sense of depth and orientation is lost; only very dark, nearby objects can be seen
It occurs over an unbroken snow cover and beneath a uniformly overcast sky when, with the aid of the snowblink effect, the light from the sky is about equal to that from the snow surface
learning.explanation: FLAT LIGHT / PARTIAL WHITEOUT "An atmospheric optical phenomenon of the polar regions in which the observer appears to be engulfed in a uniformly white glow. Neither shadows, horizon nor clouds are discernible; sense of depth and orientation is lost; only very dark, nearby objects can be seen. It occurs over an unbroken snow cover and beneath a uniformly overcast sky when, with the aid of the snowblink effect, the light from the sky is about equal to that from the snow surface." More simply put, the phenomenon occurs when you are in the presence of a large flat area and the overcast sky blends in with the ground. You get the impression of being inside a bowl of milk or a ping-pong ball. It is impossible to make out the horizon and distance from the ground. This has led to accidents involving CFIT in the past.

content.question: Identifying landmarks and overall orientation and visualisation of the inflight situation on a VFR flight can be made easy by:

options.B: Holding the complete map with track-up orientation.
options.C: Holding a relevant part of the map with track-up orientation.
options.D: Holding only a small part of the map with North-up orientation.

key_points: In VFR flights, the aeronautical chart consists the basis of VFR navigation

One of the most common methods to navigate under VFR is by selecting, during the pre-flight planning procedure, the ground features, which are marked on the VFR chart and then seeking for them on the ground during the flight

The VFR charts depict topographic features and other information of interest to pilots flying visually, such as major landmarks, terrain elevations, visual navigation routes, ground-based navigation aids, airports, rivers, cities, airspace boundaries, etc
learning.explanation: In VFR flights, the aeronautical chart consists the basis of VFR navigation. One of the most common methods to navigate under VFR is by selecting, during the pre-flight planning procedure, the ground features, which are marked on the VFR chart and then seeking for them on the ground during the flight. The VFR charts depict topographic features and other information of interest to pilots flying visually, such as major landmarks, terrain elevations, visual navigation routes, ground-based navigation aids, airports, rivers, cities, airspace boundaries, etc. During VFR navigation, the cadets are usually instructed to hold the map oriented to the direction of flight, so that the surrounding topographic features can be easily identified, i.e. hold the map so that direction of flight is at the top (not North), also known as "track-up", so "right" on the map will correspond to "right" on the ground and map reading will be easier. Using the chart “track-up”, gives the best situational awareness to the crew and it can also be useful to check if the aircraft is on the planned position by checking if the ground features coincide with your expectations. Also, for convenience during flight, it is not necessary to hold the whole navigation chart, but it is preferred to hold only a a relevant with the trip part of the whole chart, so as not to reduce the pilot's field of view and handling effectiveness. "North-up" map orientation is mainly suggested for flight planning.

content.question: Which one of the following situations mostly increases the risk of Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) during a VFR flight?

key_points: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain, while an aircraft is under positive control
CFIT occurs when an airworthy aircraft under the complete control of the pilot is inadvertently flown into terrain, water, or an obstacle
The pilots are generally unaware of the danger until it is too late
learning.explanation: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain, while an aircraft is under positive control. CFIT occurs when an airworthy aircraft under the complete control of the pilot is inadvertently flown into terrain, water, or an obstacle. The pilots are generally unaware of the danger until it is too late. Many CFIT accidents occur because of loss of situational awareness and may happen not only in night or IMC conditions, but even in a VFR flight during the day. Accidents where the aircraft is out of control at the point of impact are not known as CFIT. Rather, they are considered uncontrolled flight into terrain. Similarly, incidents resulting from deliberate acts, such as terrorism or suicide by the pilot, are also not considered to be CFIT. Overcast sky and Snow-Covered Terrain - CORRECT: This is a situation where the snow-covered terrain and the overcast sky are mixed making the horizon invisible. The lack of the poor colour contrast, ground features and shadows increase the likelihood of loss of situational awareness by the pilot, creating illusions of climbing or descending while he/she actually flies level.

However, It's essential to recognize that the usefulness of features with substantial vertical extent may decrease as you fly at higher altitudes. When flying at 5,000 feet above ground level (AGL), a 400-foot-high mast might become difficult to spot due to its diminished visual prominence. "A railroad perpendicular to the track." CORRECT. This is a conspicuous landmark with a great extent which can be easily located and identified from the altitude at which a VFR flight is normally operating. since this road is crossing perpendicularly the planned track, the crossing point could be used to check for any time deviation and to calculate the actual ground speed. "A straight highway along the calculated track." INCORRECT. A landmark, even if easily identifiable, is not useful to check the aircraft's groundspeed as it wil not be crossing the path at any point. When flying, because of the great extent along the track, a second conspicuous landmark close to the crossing point is required. "A large waterway in the direction of the aircraft’s nose." INCORRECT. While a large waterway can be a visual reference point and used as a checkpoint, it may not be as accurate or easy to measure ground speed as a perpendicular railroad track. Determining ground speed using a waterway may involve more challenges including, in this case, lack of perpendicular reference: Unlike a railroad track, which runs perpendicular to your flight path, a waterway may or may not be at a right angle to your track. Measuring the time it takes to fly over a distance along the waterway may not directly correspond to your ground speed due to the angle between your flight path and the waterway.

key_points: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain (the ground, a mountain, a body of water, or an obstacle) while an aircraft is under positive control
Most often, the pilot or crew is unaware of the looming disaster until it is too late
Accidents where the aircraft is out of control at the point of impact are not known as CFIT
learning.explanation: Controlled Flight into Terrain (CFIT) is defined as an unintentional collision with terrain (the ground, a mountain, a body of water, or an obstacle) while an aircraft is under positive control. Most often, the pilot or crew is unaware of the looming disaster until it is too late. Accidents where the aircraft is out of control at the point of impact are not known as CFIT. Rather, they are considered uncontrolled flight into terrain. Similarly, incidents resulting from deliberate acts, such as terrorism or suicide by the pilot, are also not considered to be CFIT. One major factor of CFIT is the loss of situational awareness — failing to know at all times what the aircraft’s position is, how that position relates to the altitude of the surface immediately below and ahead, and how both relate to the course being flown. One of the contributory factors is weather: Rain, turbulence, clouds and icing, may increase the workload of the pilot and cause interference reducing the accuracy of radio navigation beacons. Poor visibility, particularly at night can contribute to disorientation and loss of situational awareness.

content.question:
True Track = 085°
GS = 180 kt
W/V = 290°/30 kt
Var = 4°E
Calculate the Track Error Angle if the aircraft is 1.5 NM left of track after 12 minutes of flying.

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE: TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 Planned track distance flown = 180 x 12’ = 36 NM TE = (1.5/36) x 60 = 2.5º L

Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart. Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring. learning.explanation: VFR checkpoints are visual references on the ground that pilots use to help navigate during VFR flights. These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air. When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude. They should have unique features that differentiate them from other nearby object. Prominence: Checkpoints should stand out from their surroundings. They could be easily recognizable structures, geographical features, or landmarks that can be seen from a distance. Contrast with Terrain: Checkpoints should exhibit visual contrast with the surrounding terrain. This contrast can result from differences in color, texture, shape, or elevation. Proximity to Intended Path: Optimal VFR checkpoints lie directly on or in close proximity to the planned flight track, enhancing navigation accuracy. Planned Altitude Consideration: When selecting checkpoints, the intended cruising altitude must be considered. Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration. The selected feature has a white colour. On a winter day, during a special VFR flight with low clouds, reduced visibility, and a snowy surface, the feature will have the same colour with the ground and the surrounding features. This means that it will not make any visual contrast with the surrounding terrain and the pilot will find it extremely difficult to recognize it.

Frequent changes may be needed to maintain the correct airspeed, while climbing or descending over undulating ground. The view ahead and around is restricted by the next fold of high ground. The angle at which you are looking becomes flatter and if a feature does not have some vertical extent, you are unlikely to see it at low level. A selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Thus, it will be difficult to fly past them.

As you plan your route, use your sectional to search for easily identifiable points along your route

learning.explanation: Checkpoints are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. As you plan your route, use your sectional to search for easily identifiable points along your route. Avoid picking points that are more than 5 miles laterally away from your route. PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance. Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice. Here's a list of some of the easiest points to spot from the air: Airports with Paved Runways: The taxiways and runways of nearby airports are easy to spot due to large clearings. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower?

5 MHz and make a PAN call; If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on route plan heading; Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position; Compare the ground with your estimated position on the map (look at the terrain for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, railway, river or coastline; Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading (and look out for other aircraft) and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as a lake, wood, built-up area, mast or a combination of roads, rivers and railways

content.question: What is the danger about power lines when flying VFR over a snowy area?

options.A: Always marked on the map, no problem.
options.B: Due to their small vertical extents, not a factor.
options.C: Represent a danger when flying over a mountain's ridge.
options.D: Represent a danger when power lines cross a valley.

key_points: For this question examine each statement carefully: "Always marked on the map, no problem
" - Incorrect: Usually only the high voltage power lines are depicted on a chart, but not always

The pilot flying VFR must be very careful with the power lines, especially during take-off or landing, where the required altitude which provides obstacle clearance has not been reached yet or the aircraft is quite below the minimum safe altitude correspongingly
learning.explanation: For this question examine each statement carefully: "Always marked on the map, no problem." - Incorrect: Usually only the high voltage power lines are depicted on a chart, but not always. The pilot flying VFR must be very careful with the power lines, especially during take-off or landing, where the required altitude which provides obstacle clearance has not been reached yet or the aircraft is quite below the minimum safe altitude correspongingly. "Due to their small vertical extents, not a factor." - Incorrect: The low voltage power lines have indeed a small vertical extent, but the high voltage ones have a greater one, posing the flight at risk when flying at low altitude. "Represent a danger when flying over a mountain's ridge." - Incorrect: When flying over snow covered mountain ridges in overcast low cloud ceiling conditions, the poor contrast makes it difficult for the pilot to distinguish the sky from the ground and a false perception of the distance, depth and altitude is created with an invisible horizon. But, the power lines are rarely installed over mountain ridges and if installed their height is quite low. "Represent a danger when power lines cross a valley." - CORRECT: In most cases the power lines cross valleys rather than ridges. Over a snowy area, the high voltage power lines can be easily distinguished, but not the low voltage ones due to their smaller vertical extent.

A pilot planning a VFR flight leg is looking for a ground feature part-way a long a leg that is NOT in built up area. All of the following are depicted on the VFR chart in suitable locations for a visual fix. Which might allow the pilot to check for any drifting error along the track?
1. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing the intended track.
2. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing a river close to the intended track.
3. Disused railway crossing a river on intended track.
4. Single carriageway (two line) road crossing a railway close to intended track.

key_points: To check for drifting errors along the intended track during VFR flight, it's essential to identify conspicuous landmarks close to the track
These landmarks should be easily locatable and distinguishable from the VFR flight altitude
Using these landmarks, pilots can monitor flight progress and calculate ground speed
learning.explanation: To check for drifting errors along the intended track during VFR flight, it's essential to identify conspicuous landmarks close to the track. These landmarks should be easily locatable and distinguishable from the VFR flight altitude. Using these landmarks, pilots can monitor flight progress and calculate ground speed. "1. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing the intended track." INCORRECT. This is a prominent landmark, yet its vast expanse presents challenges for pilots in accurately identifying the precise crossing point from the air. As a result, it is advisable not to rely solely on this landmark for drift error checks. "2. Dual-carriageway (four line) road crossing a river close to the intended track." CORRECT. This prominent landmark lies in close proximity to the intended flight track, distinguished by its substantial size and stark contrast against the surroundings. During the planning stage, pilots can use its position as a reference point relative to the track. While in-flight, comparing the aircraft's position with this easily identifiable landmark on the chart enables the assessment of any potential drift error. "3. Disused railway crossing a river on intended track." CORRECT. Even though the railway line is disused, the point where this railway line crosses the river can be easily located due to the color contrast with the surroundings. "Single carriageway (two line) road crossing a railway close to intended track." CORRECT. Similar to a Dual-carriageway (four-line) road, this conspicuous landmark lies in close proximity to the intended flight track and can be easily located and identified from the altitude of a VFR (Visual Flight Rules) flight. By cross-referencing the aircraft's position relative to this landmark during the flight, the pilot can pinpoint their location on the chart and assess for any potential drift error.
