learning.explanation: NOTE: There is another question in the database that is similar to this question (615463) and asks for the best VFR features, but it has different options. We have seen many different feedback for these questions and we believe there are several versions used by EASA. So far the ‘rule’ for these questions is that ‘farmland’ is never correct and if high-tension power lines are present, they are correct (this is a debatable point, but sometimes a good VFR feature, particularly in forested areas). After that, it is common sense. Checkpoints are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. PICKING THE BEST CHECKPOINTS Finding a good VFR checkpoint is a matter of location, size, and distance. Large objects that contrast well with the surrounding environment are the best choice. Ground features on or close to track are preferred. Here's a list of some of the easiest points to spot from the air: Airports with Paved Runways: The taxiways and runways of nearby airports are easy to spot due to large clearings. They also contrast with the grass around them. Railroads: Railroads are relatively easy to spot due to large clearings made for tracks. Highways: Multi-lane highways are easy to spot from the air. Major Road Intersections: Major road and highway intersections with multiple cloverleaf turnoffs are easily spotted. Large Rivers: Looks for rivers that are drawn with some level of open-water width. Small streams are simple lines, while rivers are drawn wider on your sectional chart. Large Lakes with Definable Shapes: If a lake has an easily definable shape, it'll be easy to spot from the air. Towns with Prominent Features: Does the town you're looking for have a major road, railway, or water tower? Tall Towers or Masts: Easy to see at low level and always marked on charts due to their height, they can be excellent features for VFR navigation, as long as they aren't tall enough to hit. Power lines aren't always good as some have thin wires that don't stand out very well, but they are large features and cause large clearings to be made, which are easy to spot, particularly in a forest. Telephone lines, on the other hand, are much smaller and VERY difficult to see from high up. And, a farmland provides low contrast with the surroundings as it may be mistaken with similar field nearby.

learning.explanation: VFR navigation is highly affected by the choice of route, and particularly features to use for turning points or tracking. In this case, with quite poor visibility, due to the haze and the Sun to the West, the best way to navigate given here is to use the large line features of the highway and the river, which can be followed all the way to the destination. It does not add too much distance to the route, but does make sure that the pilot will always know their position and will not become lost or disorientated. The tall mast may be an acceptable turning point, but might be difficult to identify in the Sun and the haze, and the long legs with reduced visibility could lead the aircraft to being off course and have a higher chance of getting the pilot lost than following the highway and river. We think that this question is the most representative of the current feedback, but please do let us know if you see any similar question in the real exam, and anything you remember about it, thank you There are some generic ways to deal with position uncertainty listed below, but in this case, the pilot should tune DET VOR/DME and fly straight towards it, using a previously calculated direction if no signal is received

learning.explanation: Note: We have received some varying feedback for this question and the statements involved. We think that this question is the most representative of the current feedback, but please do let us know if you see any similar question in the real exam, and anything you remember about it, thank you There are some generic ways to deal with position uncertainty listed below, but in this case, the pilot should tune DET VOR/DME and fly straight towards it, using a previously calculated direction if no signal is received. As they are no longer on their flight planned route, following the OFP is not very useful, and the low cloud means they cannot climb higher whilst remaining VMC. When a pilot becomes in doubt about their position, they should perform some or all of the following actions: 1. Note the time. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. 3. Consider using any radio-navigation aids that may be available to give position information. 4. If short of fuel or near controlled airspace and not in contact with ATC, set 121.5 MHz and make a PAN call. 5. If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on the planned heading. 6. Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position. 7. Compare the ground with the aircraft's estimated position on the map. When the aircraft’s position is uncertain, ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. Line features such as coastlines, railways, large highways, etc. can be easy to find and useful to then fly along until you can find your position on the map. 8. Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as hills, valleys, lakes, wood, built-up areas, rivers, coastlines, motorways and railways. In any case, maintain VMC and visual contact with the ground, note the fuel state and, if necessary, try to identify an area suitable for a precautionary landing.

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station

learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 010º 15ºE 355º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 30º right is the same as RBI 030º. Aircraft’s True Track from the island, QTE = 030º + 010º +180º = 220º (T)

options.C: Flying with the sun behind the aircraft.
options.D: Sun is high in the sky.

key_points: The pilots flying VFR must check if the sky is obscured, meaning that something is totally or partially blocking his/her view of either the sky or the ground
Obscurations (and their abbreviations) include: mist (BR), fog (FG), smoke (FU), volcanic ash (VA), sand (SA), haze (HZ), spray (PY), and widespread dust (DU)
Smoke may come from factories and forest fires
learning.explanation: The pilots flying VFR must check if the sky is obscured, meaning that something is totally or partially blocking his/her view of either the sky or the ground. Obscurations (and their abbreviations) include: mist (BR), fog (FG), smoke (FU), volcanic ash (VA), sand (SA), haze (HZ), spray (PY), and widespread dust (DU). Smoke may come from factories and forest fires. Even far downwind of smoke, the smoke is often spread out, somewhat uniformly, within the bottom several low levels of the atmosphere. In some cases the smoke is so thick that it is difficult to see the bottom parts of the clouds and can reduce visibility to the point, where it is a hazard to aviation. Furthermore, visibility may be also reduced, if flying with the sun in front of the aircraft or with the Sun low in the sky.

A good way to spot and follow them is to find the power line pylons
They’re more visible than the power line itself, so easier to identify
learning.explanation: Unless you’re flying quite low, power lines may be another tricky ground feature. A good way to spot and follow them is to find the power line pylons. They’re more visible than the power line itself, so easier to identify. Being a high obstacle over the ground in icing conditions and over an area covered by snow the high pylons will stand out cause the snow will not stack over the power line pylons. The same for high antennas which are identified on the VFR charts. The question should be clearer because it depends on the time of the year, on the conditions (if there was some snow and/or cold temperatures before, and for how long) and EASA should also mention the location. Depending on conditions and location, rivers can freeze. Several students confirmed that "high-tension lines" was correct in their official examination and that the answers given were "high-tension lines" (instead of "electrical line") and "river" (instead of large river), so we changed the question and correct answer in 2 016-06. The correct answer before was "a large river". If this question appears differently in your official examination, please let us know.

content.question: What is the best visual reporting point for an aircraft flying a VFR flight above a hilly area?

options.B: Few small rivers that leave a big river.

key_points: Visual reporting points are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air
The choice of ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air
So, among others, you should also consider the uniqueness and the contrast of the ground features
learning.explanation: Visual reporting points are prominent buildings or landmarks that can be visually easy to identify from the air. The choice of ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. So, among others, you should also consider the uniqueness and the contrast of the ground features. After examining the options given below the answer, we come to the following conclusions: The contrast of an object to its background has a notable effect on its visibility. If contrast is high (for example a valley against a hilly area), then the range at which objects can be seen is increased. A hill or a slightly steeper hillside within a hilly area does not provide uniqueness. Also, few small rivers that leave a big river may provide contrast, regarding the colours against the surrounding environment, but they are not unique. The big river at its own could be a preferable ground feature as a visual reporting point contrary to the few small rivers. Therefore, the best visual reporting point for an aircraft flying a VFR flight above a hilly area, seems to be a valley.

content.question: An aircraft is making a VFR flight under freezing conditions after recent heavy snow fall. Which of the following land marks will provide the most reliable reference?

options.B: A railway track (without an overhead line).

key_points: "A railway track (without an overhead line)
" and "A country road
" Incorrect
learning.explanation: "A railway track (without an overhead line)." and "A country road." Incorrect. Question states recent heavy snow fall. In such conditions, country roads and railways would most likely be covered in snow and very hard to spot. "A river." Incorrect. Depending on the conditions and location, rivers can freeze (especially small rivers). This would make it difficult to spot them, they would blend in with the surroundings (snow covered fields). "A high-tension power line (with towers)." Correct. Snow would not fully cover a high tension power line. Additionally, most high tension power lines have Brightly Colored Balls (visibility marker balls) => these will help make power lines more obvious to low-flying aircraft like planes and helicopters.

content.question: An aircraft is flying a low-level VFR route over a mountainous area, which is covered by snow, in high latitudes. Power lines are...

options.A: Dangerous, especially if they cross valleys, but pose less of a risk if they are situated along ridge.
options.B: Dangerous if they are situated along a ridge, but pose less of a risk of they are crossing a valley.
options.C: Easily identified, as they are always marked on maps and can therefore be safely avoided.
options.D: Safely overflown due to their small vertical extent.

key_points: Power lines can be difficult to see, especially in areas with low visibility due to weather conditions, such as snow or fog
When flying over a mountainous area, power lines can pose a significant hazard to low-level flights, particularly if they cross valleys
In such cases, the pilot may not be able to see the power lines until it's too late to take evasive action
learning.explanation: Power lines can be difficult to see, especially in areas with low visibility due to weather conditions, such as snow or fog. When flying over a mountainous area, power lines can pose a significant hazard to low-level flights, particularly if they cross valleys. In such cases, the pilot may not be able to see the power lines until it's too late to take evasive action. Power lines situated along a ridge may be easier to see, but they still pose a risk, especially if the aircraft is flying close to the ridge. It's important for pilots flying low-level VFR routes to exercise caution and remain vigilant for power lines. Maps and charts can help identify potential hazards, but they may not always be up-to-date or accurate. In addition, some power lines may not be marked on charts, so pilots should always be on the lookout for any obstacles that may pose a risk to their flight. The small vertical extent of power lines is not a guarantee of safety, and pilots should always maintain a safe altitude and distance from any potential hazards.

content.question: Which features are the most suitable when flying a VFR flight at low level during the daylight, using checkpoints on a 1:500 000 map?

options.A: Ones that are tall and prominent, such as towers.
options.B: Small ones, such as individual houses distributed over an area of farmland.
options.C: Very large ones, such as an extensive wooded area.
options.D: Minor roads in a built up area.

key_points: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg
Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air
Thus, the pilot should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred
learning.explanation: When planning a route, the pilot will use visual check points to monitor the flight progress along a flight leg. Choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps, do not necessarily show up well from the air. Thus, the pilot should consider: Proximity to planned track: Ground features on or close to the track are preferred. Size and uniqueness: Large objects with colour contrast and/or some vertical extent will be easier to identify. Time of the year: Changes in vegetation or snow cover can cause the same landscape to take on a different appearance at different times of the year. Planned Altitude: At lower levels, a selected visual check point may be hidden by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Towers are the most suitable ground features for VFR navigation, if they are unique, since they are tall and prominent with enough vertical extent and can be easily identified from the air. A chart of 1: 500 000 scale is considered as a well enough detailed aeronautical chart, but not so much that small buildings, like individual houses or minor roads can be depicted. Extensive wooden areas cover a very large area, thus cannot be considered as checkpoints and their appearance changes throughout the year.

content.question: On a VFR flight during night, which one of the following has to be considered by a pilot most carefully?

options.A: The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated.
options.B: Use of red lights in the cockpit can cause temporary blindness for pilots.
options.C: When looking outside at lit objects, it can cause disorientation with respect to the instrument readings.
options.D: Terrain and obstacles along an approach may not be clearly visible.

key_points: "The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated
" - Incorrect

Between sunset and sunrise, all aircraft in flight shall display anti-collision lights to attract attention, navigation lights to indicate the relative path of the aircraft to an observer and landing lights may be used in addition to the anti-collision lights to enhance aircraft cospicuity
learning.explanation: "The trajectory of other aircraft will not be clear, unless their landing lights are illuminated." - Incorrect. Between sunset and sunrise, all aircraft in flight shall display anti-collision lights to attract attention, navigation lights to indicate the relative path of the aircraft to an observer and landing lights may be used in addition to the anti-collision lights to enhance aircraft cospicuity. "Use of red lights in the cockpit can cause temporary blindness for pilots." - Incorrect. The cockpit lighting must be adjusted to improve the night vision and reduce reflections. Cockpit lighting at night is sometimes a red light, because it will affect the rods used for night vision, less than the white light. "When looking outside at lit objects, it can cause disorientation with respect to the instrument readings." - Incorrect. When starring at a single point of light against a dark background, it can appear to move on its own. Disorientation is likely when there are fewer visual cues and references, such as horizon and other line features. "Terrain and obstacles along an approach may not be clearly visible." - Correct. Even though there is unlimited visibility during night and not a cloud in the sky, obstacles and terrain may not be that easy to see.

content.question: Which is the best visual ground feature to establish a checkpoint for a day VFR flight over a mountainous area for an aircraft A flying at 1 000 ft AGL and an aircraft B flying at 5 000 ft AGL?

options.A: High mast for A and big lake for B.
options.B: Big lake for A and high mast for B.
options.C: High mast for both A and B.
options.D: Big lake for both A and B.

Among the criteria for the ground feature selection is its size: A big lake is a good choice for VFR navigation and monitoring the flight progress

But, flying at lower levels, objects may only appear when you are close to them and when they are not obscured by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time
learning.explanation: Generally, when flying VFR, the choice of ground features is critical, as things that show up well on a map do not necessarily show up well from the air. Among the criteria for the ground feature selection is its size: A big lake is a good choice for VFR navigation and monitoring the flight progress. But, flying at lower levels, objects may only appear when you are close to them and when they are not obscured by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time. Thus, tall, prominent with enough vertical extent and easily identified from the air ground features, such as a high mast must be selected in this case. Therefore, the best ground feature for a low VFR flight at 1 000 ft AGL (aircraft A) is a high mast and for a higher one at 5 000 ft (aircraft B) is a big lake.

content.question: A pilot has planned a VFR trip by day but, due to weather delays, must now undertake the same flight at night, with clear weather. Which of the following threats pose the greatest risk to their flight?

options.A: Tall masts and other well lit obstacles.
options.B: Difficulty recognising the aerodrome from its beacon.
options.C: Difficulty recognising populated areas, including well lit ones.
options.D: Inability to recognise fixes planned for navigating during the day.

key_points: “Tall masts and other well lit obstacles
” Incorrect
Well lit obstacles such as tall masts are particularly easy to see at night, due to their required lighting
learning.explanation: “Tall masts and other well lit obstacles.” Incorrect. Well lit obstacles such as tall masts are particularly easy to see at night, due to their required lighting. “Difficulty recognising the aerodrome from its beacon.” Incorrect Aerodrome beacons are intended to be used to identify the aerodrome at night, so this is its very purpose. “Difficulty recognising populated areas, including well lit ones.” Incorrect Illuminated populated areas can be very useful for helping pilots locate their position. It does not pose a threat to night flying. “Inability to recognise fixes planned for navigating during the day.” Correct. Some of the fixes chosen for day flight may be not clearly distinct at night. Some examples are rivers, road intersections, if they are unlighted and it is a dark night, they will not be clearly visible. Additionally, any unlighted obstacles pose a very serious threat to VFR flights at night. The pilot should be informed on the unlighted obstacles to avoid collisions.

content.question: An NDB station is observed on a relative bearing of 45° left of the aircraft’s nose. Three minutes later the same NDB station is observed on a relative bearing of 90° left of the aircraft’s nose. The W/V is calm and the aircraft GS is 120 kt. What is the minimum distance between the aircraft and the NDB station?

key_points: Let's start by determining the distance flown in 3 min (Distance1): Distance1 = 120 x 3 / 60 = 6 NM We know that the Relative bearing at first position is 45˚ to the left
Therefore, triangle angle at airplane location at old position equals 45˚
After three minutes, the Relative bearing is 90˚ to the left
learning.explanation: Let's start by determining the distance flown in 3 min (Distance1): Distance1 = 120 x 3 / 60 = 6 NM We know that the Relative bearing at first position is 45˚ to the left. Therefore, triangle angle at airplane location at old position equals 45˚. After three minutes, the Relative bearing is 90˚ to the left. Therefore, after three minutes, the angle in the triangle at airplane location equals 90˚. Difference in bearings = 45˚ Therefore, triangle angle at NDB location = 45˚ As we have triangle with 2 angles of 45˚, it is an isosceles triangle. Therefore, distance flown in 3 minutes (6 NM) equals distance from airplane new location to NDB = 6 NM

content.question: What is required to establish a track plot?

options.A: The last position, air position and DR position.
options.B: The air position and a pinpoint.
options.C: The last position and the DR position.

key_points: TRACK PLOT A continuous record on a chart of an aircraft's tracks and distances flown
The position of the aircraft, determined by pinpoints, fixes, or DR (dead reckoning) calculations, is plotted at intervals on a chart
These positions are used to determine the aircraft's progress and to calculate future positions, ETAs, and any corrections of headings that may be necessary
learning.explanation: TRACK PLOT A continuous record on a chart of an aircraft's tracks and distances flown. The position of the aircraft, determined by pinpoints, fixes, or DR (dead reckoning) calculations, is plotted at intervals on a chart. These positions are used to determine the aircraft's progress and to calculate future positions, ETAs, and any corrections of headings that may be necessary. content.question:
What are problems associated with VFR navigation (without GPS) over low-flying desert late in the morning at about 11 AM?
1. Good navigation features might be widely separated.
2. Visual range is likely to be restricted.
3. Maps might be incomplete or out-of-date.

key_points: Good navigation features might be widely separated
" Correct
learning.explanation: "1. Good navigation features might be widely separated." Correct. Over the desert, you may find yourself flying over extensive areas with little to no distinguishable natural terrain/vegetation or man-made structures. Good navigation features are often widely separated. "3. Maps might be incomplete or out-of-date." Correct. This affects all navigation (not only over the desert).

content.question: An island appears 60° to the left of the centre line on an airborne weather radar display. What is the true bearing of the aircraft from the island if at the time of observation the aircraft was on a magnetic heading (MH) of 276° with the magnetic variation (VAR) 10°E?

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 286º 10ºE 276º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 60º left is the same as RBI 300º. Aircraft’s True Track from the island, QTE = 300º + 286º + 180º = 766º 766º - 2 x 360º = 46º (T) In other words, 286º is true heading of aircraft and island is at 060º left, which means it is at 226º from aircraft. This is QUJ. QTE is the reciprocal of this one. From island the aircraft's bearing is at 046º.

content.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints and you get lost. What should you do?

options.A: Climb to a higher level and initiate the lost procedure.
options.C: Proceed and turn at the next checkpoint based on time.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: There exist two akin questions within the database (613885)
This question specifies the pilot being lost
In cases where the pilot cannot verify their position, it is advised to initiate the "unsure of position" procedure
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: There exist two akin questions within the database (613885). This question specifies the pilot being lost. In cases where the pilot cannot verify their position, it is advised to initiate the "unsure of position" procedure. Should the pilot be unable to ascertain their position even after, they should proceed with the "lost procedure." Nevertheless, if the pilot possesses knowledge of their location, they should proceed according to the original plan. One of the pilot's major concern during flight is the terrain separation. Climbing to a higher level is the best action to take in case you get lost. This will ensure obstacle clearance even when visibility is poor. Finally, when at a safe altitude, if you are still not able to confirm your position, you may need to go into the "unsure of position" procedure and if unable to establish your position adopt the "lost procedure".

content.question: Which of the following ground features should allow a Pilot flying along a VFR track to best check for any time deviation?

In case of tracking errors, because of an actual wind other than forecast, line features can be used that will lead you onto a turning point, avoiding the need for Dead Reckoning navigation method
learning.explanation: Line feature is a single and distinctive observed position line, which crosses the intended track and is ideal for timing or groundspeed check, such as a river, railway, road, ridge or tree line. In case of tracking errors, because of an actual wind other than forecast, line features can be used that will lead you onto a turning point, avoiding the need for Dead Reckoning navigation method.

content.question: The best visual marking for a VFR flight on a warm summer day is:

content.question: What is the only advantage for a pilot to keep a VFR chart oriented to True North while navigating visually in flight?

options.A: Aeronautical and topographical information can be easily read.
options.B: Allows to identify a line feature and to track the progress.
options.C: The chart can be folded and stored more easily in-flight.
options.D: Visualisation of the surrounding terrain is easier.

key_points: IMPORTANT NOTE: We've noticed that different CAAs have different right answers for this question
Please keep sharing your feedback with each other and with us in the comments, it is always useful, especially with questions like this
We have added a table to the explanation to easily convey our current knowledge of which authorities are choosing which answer
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: We've noticed that different CAAs have different right answers for this question. Please keep sharing your feedback with each other and with us in the comments, it is always useful, especially with questions like this. We have added a table to the explanation to easily convey our current knowledge of which authorities are choosing which answer. Thanks again! Authority Reported answer Poland B UK A It seems that there might be two versions of this question, one asking why the pilot should keep his/her chart oriented to True North and the other why s/he should keep the chart oriented to True track. The correct option will differ whether it asks for True North or true track. It is advisable that the VFR chart should be lined up with the current track so that it depicts what you see outside. It is also easier to identify line features such as roads, rivers, and coastlines and track their progress along those features. This is particularly important for visual navigation, where the pilot relies on visual references to navigate, as it helps them to maintain situational awareness and stay on course. For instance, expected ground features left/right of the planned track on the chart can be spotted and identified easily on the ground. Orientation to the track direction helps the pilot to maintain situational awareness. The pilot can easily identify the location of the aircraft in relation to the surrounding terrain and navigation aids, which is essential for making safe and efficient navigation decisions. However, if the question asks the reason why the chart should be oriented to True North the correct is "Aeronautical and topographical information can be easily read." If you need to read a frequency, for example, you should turn the chart to True North.

content.question: A pilot is preparing a VFR cross-country flight over hilly terrain, using visual checkpoints. Which of the following statements is true?

options.A: Isolated and prominent hills provide a good opportunity for check features.
options.B: A range of hills of uniform size, with NO additional features, is the best terrain to maintain good visual checkpoints.
options.C: The interpretation of topography from the map is easier than the interpretation of water features.
options.D: Small rivers will be easy to spot in hilly terrain.

key_points: VFR checkpoints are visual references on the ground that pilots use to help navigate during VFR flights
These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air

When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude
learning.explanation: VFR checkpoints are visual references on the ground that pilots use to help navigate during VFR flights. These checkpoints are selected based on certain characteristics to ensure they are easily recognizable and can be reliably identified from the air. When choosing VFR checkpoints, the following should be taken into account: Size and Distinctiveness: Favorable checkpoints exhibit considerable size, since they must be identified even when observed from a considerable distance or altitude. They should have unique features that differentiate them from other nearby object. Prominence: Checkpoints should stand out from their surroundings. They could be easily recognizable structures, geographical features, or landmarks that can be seen from a distance. Contrast with Terrain: Checkpoints should exhibit visual contrast with the surrounding terrain. This contrast can result from differences in color, texture, shape, or elevation. Proximity to Intended Path: Optimal VFR checkpoints lie directly on or in close proximity to the planned flight track, enhancing navigation accuracy. Planned Altitude Consideration: When selecting checkpoints, the intended cruising altitude must be considered. Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration. 'Isolated and prominent hills provide a good opportunity for check features.' ⇒ Correct Isolated and prominent hills stand out from their surroundings and have a considerable size. Therefore, they are appropriate ground features during VFR navigation. 'A range of hills of uniform size, with NO additional features, is the best terrain to maintain good visual checkpoints.' ⇒ Incorrect A range of hills of uniform size, with no additional features will not make any contrast with the surrounding terrain and will not help the pilot identify them during VFR navigation. 'The interpretation of topography from the map is easier than the interpretation of water features.' ⇒ Incorrect The difficulty of interpretetion depends on the altitude of the aircraft and their surroundings. 'Small rivers will be easy to spot in hilly terrain.' ⇒ Incorrect Lower altitudes might obscure a chosen reference point due to elevated terrain, or it might only become visible once the aircraft has traversed over it for a limited duration.

But, flying at lower levels, objects may only appear when you are close to them and when they are not obscured by high ground or only visible after the aircraft has passed over it and for a limited period of time
learning.explanation: Generally, when flying VFR, the choice of ground features is critical, as things that show up well on a map do not necessarily show up well from the air. Among the criteria for the ground feature selection is its size: A large lake is a better choice for VFR navigation and monitoring the flight progress, in comparison with a path or a small lake. content.question: A pilot has prepared for a VFR flight in daytime. The flight is delayed, and the pilot decides to carry out the flight late at night with clear weather and good visibility forecast. Which of the following is the most significant hazard that the pilot should consider to planning for the night flight?

options.A: Limited visibility of navigation features that were selected for the original plan.
options.B: Increased fatigue and reduced alertness due to the pilot's circadian rhythm and biological factors.
options.C: Difficulty in identifying the airfield by their beacons.
options.D: Greater hazard associated with in obstacles such tall masts at night compared to during the day.

key_points: During the day, the pilot can easily rely on visual cues such as natural landmarks, roads, rivers, and towns to navigate
However, at night, visibility of these navigation features is significantly reduced, making it challenging to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references
Without adequate visual references, the pilot may have difficulty maintaining situational awareness and staying on course, increasing the risk of getting lost or deviating from the intended route
learning.explanation: During the day, the pilot can easily rely on visual cues such as natural landmarks, roads, rivers, and towns to navigate. However, at night, visibility of these navigation features is significantly reduced, making it challenging to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references. Without adequate visual references, the pilot may have difficulty maintaining situational awareness and staying on course, increasing the risk of getting lost or deviating from the intended route. At night, you can see illuminated objects only, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. The other options mentioned are also important considerations for night VFR flights, but limited visibility of navigation features is the most significant hazard because it directly affects the pilot's ability to navigate safely and accurately during the flight. Tall obstacles at night are properly marked, and can be managed with proper planning, preparation, and adherence to procedures designed for night flying.

content.question: Which one of the following VFR navigation techniques provides to a pilot the maximum amount of time to check for other traffic and also maintain a good situational awareness?

options.A: Plan to fly from point to point as identified on the map and then on the ground.
options.B: Keep a continuous update of the position by looking within a short distance of the aircraft.
options.C: Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track.
options.D: Delay any aircraft system checks until the aircraft is turned onto a new heading.

key_points: For this question, examine each statement carefully: "Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track

" - CORRECT: A pilot to both maximize the available time for checking the other traffic or obstacles and maintain a good situation awareness, he/she has to look for a distant and prominent visual reference landmark along the route (such as a big lake), instead of a small and close to him/her landmarks (such as a village)

In this case, each time the pilot looks around for other traffic, can easily identify the distant and prominent landmark at any time, thus spending more time for the other traffic than looking for the same landmark each time he/she takes his/her eyes off it
learning.explanation: For this question, examine each statement carefully: "Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track." - CORRECT: A pilot to both maximize the available time for checking the other traffic or obstacles and maintain a good situation awareness, he/she has to look for a distant and prominent visual reference landmark along the route (such as a big lake), instead of a small and close to him/her landmarks (such as a village). In this case, each time the pilot looks around for other traffic, can easily identify the distant and prominent landmark at any time, thus spending more time for the other traffic than looking for the same landmark each time he/she takes his/her eyes off it. Thus, "Keep a continuous update of the position by looking within a short distance of the aircraft." - Incorrect. The available time for any other activity will be shortened. "Plan to fly from point to point as identified on the map and then on the ground." - Incorrect: The Ground-to-Map VFR technique is more prefferable to the Map-to-Ground. learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdaated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid. It is likely that a route from the departure aerodrome directly to the destination will be divided into a number of route segments with the creation of turning points and waypoints. Breaking the route down into route segments brings several advantages: 1. Route segment can be selected to pass near a prominent ground feature, to help the pilot fly on track. 2. Shorter route segments minimize off-track errors by reducing the time allowed for them to develop. 3. High terrain or significant obstructions like telecommunication masts can be avoided. Really important in poor visibility conditions. Choose compact ground features as turning points and waypoints to ensure that routes are flown with precision. learning.explanation: Night flying is slightly different to daytime navigation. The pilot can see illuminated objects only, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. The so called “black-hole effect” also influences judgement, particularly distance estimation. The black hole illusion occurs when flying over featureless terrain, approaching an airfield at night over water, jungle or desert. This illusion might fool the pilots into thinking they are higher than they actually are, causing them to fly dangerously low approaches - the aircraft may touch down short of the runway. "Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness." Incorrect. "When external lighting provides good visual cues, flying by cross-reference to instruments may cause spatial disorientation." Incorrect. content.question: An aircraft is flying from A (50°S, 040°W) to B (60°S, 050°W). The initial great circle track is 206°. What will be the rhumb line track when passing 045°W?

key_points: Rhumb Lines are lines of constant direction, i
e
cut all meridians at the same angle
learning.explanation: Rhumb Lines are lines of constant direction, i.e. cut all meridians at the same angle. A rhumb line between any two points will always lie on the equatorial side of the equivalent great circle and the great circle is poleward of the rhumb line. The angle difference between the great circle and the rhumb line is called "Conversion Angle" and is half(½) the convergency. Convergency is given by the formula: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Mean Latitude. Applying the rule "Same hemisphere, Subtract", the Change of Longitude is: 050° - 040° = 10°. The Mean Latitude of A and B points is: (50° + 60°) / 2 = 55°. Thus, Convergency between A and B is: Convergency (A-B) = 10° x Sin 55° = 8° and the Conversion angle is: Conversion angle = ½ Convergency = 4°. The rhumb line track is constant, so when passing 045°W it is: Initial great circle track + Conversion angle = 206° + 4° = 210°. NOTE: A correctly drawn sketch diagram shows if the conversion angle must be added or subtracted to a great circle track. Also, meridians in the southern hemisphere are slopping out.

content.question: What is the initial track direction of a straight line on a Polar Stereographic chart when flying from position A (83°N,130°E) to position B (83°N, 160°W).

key_points: The solution requires a sketch diagram: Draw a circle which represents the 83th Parallel of Latitude, label the Greenwich meridian and draw in the East-West directions

learning.explanation: The solution requires a sketch diagram: Draw a circle which represents the 83th Parallel of Latitude, label the Greenwich meridian and draw in the East-West directions. After that, draw the local meridians 130°E and 160°W through positions A and B and the track joining them. Draw in north reference arrows on the local meridians and a "direction of travel" arrow on the track line, as a guide when measuring the angles. Draw in the track angle at A. It can be seen that the track at A is less than 90o. If we now consider the triangle formed by point A, point B and the North Pole (NP), we have an isosceles triangle with equal sides A-NP and B-NP, thus angles NP-Â-B and NP-Â-A are equal. The angle in this triangle at NP (A-NP-B) is equal to the Change of Longitude between points A and B. They are in different hemispheres, so we add the longitudes: 160o + 130o = 290o. This is more than 180o so subtract it from 360o to find the short way around. So, Change of Longitude (A-B) = 360o - 290o = 070o. The 3 angles in any triangle always add up to 180o. Since the angle at NP is 070o, the equal angles at A and B must be 055o each (070o+055o+055o=180o). Therefore, the initial track direction at A is 055o(T).

learning.explanation: A great circle track that intersects the equator will cross it once more on the opposite side of the Earth. These two crossing points will have opposite longitudes, one in the West and the other in the East, with their sum totaling 180º. content.question: Crossing the North Atlantic on a westbound track from position X (62°N, 020°W) to position Y (63°N, 030°W), the average true track is 282.2°. On a Lambert chart with standard parallels at 75°N and 30°N, the direction of the straight line is approximately…

key_points: For a Lambert chart the following convergency formula is applied: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Parallel of Origin
Average true track 282
2o is the track measured exactly in the middle point between X and Y, while crossing the 25oW meridian
learning.explanation: For a Lambert chart the following convergency formula is applied: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Parallel of Origin. Average true track 282.2o is the track measured exactly in the middle point between X and Y, while crossing the 25oW meridian. Parallel of origin is the mean latitude between the two standard parallels: (75o N + 30o N) / 2 = 52.5o N. Applying the rule, "SAME HEMISPHERES, SUBTRACT", the Change of Longitude between X and Y is: 30o W - 20o W = 10o. Thus, Convergency = 10o x sin 52,5o = 7.9o. That means that the true track from X to Y position changes by 7.9o, so until the middle point, it changes by 7.9o/2 = 3.9o. Bear in mind that both X and Y lie on the Northern hemisphere, where meridians converge inwards towards the North Pole and as we travel westwards, the true track decreases. So, true track will be greater at X than in the middle point and consequently greater in the middle point than at Y. The direction at position X is: 282.2o + 3.9o = 286,1o and The direction at position Y is: 282.2o - 3.9o = 278.3o. Therefore, the correct answer is that the approximate direction is 286o at position X.

content.question: What is the Earth convergency for a straight line between position A (37°45'S, 170°25'W) and position B (37°45'S 168°35'E)?

Because the change of direction on a straight line is a result of the converging meridians, the effect is called, Convergency, i.e. it is the change of the true track between two points as a result of the converging meridians. The formula to calculate Convergency is: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin mean latitude. For the Change of Longitude apply the rule: Different Hemispheres - Add, if greater than 180º then subtract from 360º. learning.explanation: The Mercator projection is a cylindrical map projection. It became the standard map projection for navigation because of its unique property of representing any course of constant bearing as a straight segment. Mercator projection inflates the size of objects away from the equator. This inflation starts infinitesimally, but accelerates with latitude to become infinite at the poles. key_points: The Polar Stereographic Projection is a plane projection, the parallel of origin is the pole and is created assuming a flat plate touching at the pole with the origin of the projection at the opposite pole
Meridians are straight lines radiating from the pole, which cut parallels of latitude at right angles
Parallels are shown as concentric circles and their distance apart increases away from the pole
learning.explanation: The Polar Stereographic Projection is a plane projection, the parallel of origin is the pole and is created assuming a flat plate touching at the pole with the origin of the projection at the opposite pole. Meridians are straight lines radiating from the pole, which cut parallels of latitude at right angles. Parallels are shown as concentric circles and their distance apart increases away from the pole. As we might expect, Great circles at the point of tangency would be straight lines, but the point of tangency is only a point, so you cannot draw a great circle here. Great circles that cut through this point will also be straight lines, these are the meridians. Elsewhere, the Great circles will actually be slightly curved concave to the pole, but near the pole can be assumed to be straight lines. Rhumb lines will be curves concave to the neare pole.

options.B: the meridians and parallels are perpendicular to each other.
options.C: every great circle is represented by a straight line in the map.
options.D: at any point the scale over a short distance in the direction of the parallel is equal to the scale in the direction of the meridian and the meridians are perpendicular to the parallels.

key_points: Maps and charts are referred to as "conformal" if they preserve angles during the projection
This means that a given angle on the original globe remains the same on the projection surface
Right angles between latitudes and longitudes in the graticule remain right angles during a conformal projection
learning.explanation: Maps and charts are referred to as "conformal" if they preserve angles during the projection. This means that a given angle on the original globe remains the same on the projection surface. Right angles between latitudes and longitudes in the graticule remain right angles during a conformal projection. In a conformal projection, the distortions (as a result of the projection) in east-west direction must be the same as in north-south direction at any point of the chart. Any circle on the sphere remains a circle on the other surface, but equal spherical circles do not necessarily remain equal circles on the projection surface. In summary, for a chart to be conformal, it must have: Correct shapes; A right-angled graticule; and Equal scale in all directions.

content.question: A straight line is drawn on a Lamberts conformal conic chart between two positions of different longitude. The angular difference between the initial true track and the final true track of the line is equal to:

key_points: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i
e
the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth
learning.explanation: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i.e. the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth. On a Lamberts Conformal Conical chart this is the point where the external cone forms the tangent and this parallel of latitude is known as the Parallel of Origin. In effect, the Lamberts chart is constructed from a secant cone which is placed inside the Earth - as such it intersects the Earth surface at two points, known as Standard Parallels. The Scale in Lambert conformal chart is only correct along the standard parallels. Part of the chart (outside the Standard Parallels) is outside the Earth and part (inside the Standard Parallels) is inside the Earth. The Parallel of Origin (from the outer cone) is mathematically projected onto this inner cone and is located slightly poleward of the mid-point of the Standard Parallels; however, for simplicity we assume the Parallel of Origin is half-way between the Standard Parallels, i.e. the average of the Standard Parallels. The Parallel of Origin determines the Convergence Factor for the whole chart and is equal to the Sine of this latitude, i.e. the Sine of the Parallel of Origin. The Convergence Factor is also known (on a Lamberts Chart) as the 'Constant of the Cone' or simply 'n'. Convergency: Angular difference between the initial track and final track. Conversion angle: Angular difference between initial track and rhumb line.

The position A (75°N, 34°E) of an aircraft and the position B (75°N, 50°E) of an NDB station are plotted on a polar stereographic chart projection and are connected with a straight line. Determine the true bearing from position B to position A, given:

The angle at P will be the difference between longitude of position B and position A

Therefore, the triangle APB is isosceles; and Angle at A = Angle at B. The sum of angles of a triangle equals 180º. Consequently, Angle A and Angle B: 180º - 16º = 164º 164º / 2 = 82º True bearing from position B to position A equals the angle measured clockwise from the True North at position B to the line connecting B to A. content.question: A straight line is drawn on a Lambert conformal conic chart, on which Chart Convergency = Earth Convergency at latitude 42°, from A (48°_ 155°E) to B (36°_ ___°__). The true course of the straight-line track at A is 060°T and at B is 046°T. Determine the hemisphere in which the track is drawn and the final longitude at B:

key_points: The true course along the straight-line track at position A is 060° True (in a north-easterly direction, where Point B is closer to the North compared to Point A)
This track extends from a higher latitude (48º) to a lower latitude (36º), which indicates that it is located in the Southern Hemisphere
In the Northern Hemisphere, a track between these latitudes would generally be oriented in a southerly direction
learning.explanation: The true course along the straight-line track at position A is 060° True (in a north-easterly direction, where Point B is closer to the North compared to Point A). This track extends from a higher latitude (48º) to a lower latitude (36º), which indicates that it is located in the Southern Hemisphere. In the Northern Hemisphere, a track between these latitudes would generally be oriented in a southerly direction. Now, we can exclude two options (Northern Hemisphere answers), leaving us with two remaining choices: Southern Hemisphere, 166°E Southern Hemisphere, 176°E To determine the correct option, we first need to calculate the change in longitude. The question specifies that "Chart Convergency = Earth Convergency at latitude 42°." On a Lambert chart, the Chart Convergence is only equal to Earth Convergence at the Parallel of Origin, which means that the Parallel of Origin is at 42ºS. The track at Point A is 060ºT, and at Point B, it is 046ºT. The convergency between these two tracks is calculated as follows: Convergency = 060ºT - 046ºT = 014º Using the relationship Convergency = Change of Longitude x sin (Parallel of Origin), we can solve for Change of Longitude: Change of Longitude = Convergency / sin (Parallel of Origin) Change of Longitude = 014º / 0.669 Change of Longitude = 021º Point B is situated to the east of Point A, and the Change of Longitude between the two positions is 21°, the Longitude of Point B is determined as follows: Longitude of Point B = Longitude A + Change of Longitude Longitude of Point B = 155°E + 021° = 176°E

content.question:
Refer to figure or chart E(LO)2 from the Jeppesen GSPRM 2017.
The Lamber chart has its standard parallels at 37°N and 65°N. An aircraft is flying at (N55°00.0', W011°00.0') position and its magnetic heading is 136°. The relative bearing from the aircraft to the Donegal NDB (CFN) (N55° 02.6' , W008° 20.4') is 318°. In the aircraft position, the relative bearing obtained of Donegal NDB (CFN) (N55° 02.6' , W008° 20.4') is 318°. The true bearing to be plotted from the NDB to the aircraft position is...

key_points: Bearings measured at ground station (VOR, VDF) - variation at ground station Bearings measured at aircraft (NDB/ADF, AWR) - variation at aircraft At the dead reckoning position (N55°00
0'), variation shown on the chart is 6ºW
learning.explanation: Bearings measured at ground station (VOR, VDF) - variation at ground station Bearings measured at aircraft (NDB/ADF, AWR) - variation at aircraft At the dead reckoning position (N55°00.0', W011°00.0'), variation shown on the chart is 6ºW. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: 1. Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Variation West → Magnetic Best True Heading = Magnetic Heading - Variation = 136º - 6º = 130º True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 130º 6ºW 136º 2. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to get true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. QUJ = RBI + True Heading = 318º + 130º = 448º QUJ = 448º - 360º = 88º 3. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QTE = QUJ + 180º = 88º + 180º = 268º Unlike the Mercator chart where chart convergence is zero, in a Lambert conformal chart the meridians merge with each other at the poles. To plot a bearing in a Lambert chart we must apply the chart convergence, because there is chart convergence between the meridians where the bearing is measured (aircraft) and from it will be plotted (NDB). Chart convergence = (Change in Longitude) × sin (parallel of origin) Parallel of origin = (37º + 65º) / 2 = 51º N Chart convergence = (10º - 8.33º) × sin (51º) = 2º The aircraft is flying in the northen hemisphere. The bearing to be plotted from the NDB to the aircraft has a Westerly direction, therfore the Great Circle Track decreases along the two points, and will be maximum at the NDB. True bearing to be plotted from the NDB to the aircraft = 268º + 2º = 270º

content.question: On a Lambert conformal conic chart the convergence of the meridians..

options.A: equals earth convergency at the standard parallels.
options.C: is the same as earth convergency at the parallel of origin.
options.D: varies as the secant of the latitude.

key_points: The scale on a Lambert chart is correct at the two standard parallels, because the standard parallels are the same on the globe as on the cone
The scale then decreases (contracts) between the standard parallels, reaching the minimum value at the parallel of the origin, and increases (expands) outside the parallels
The longitudes on the globe are projected into Euclidean straight lines on the cone
learning.explanation: The scale on a Lambert chart is correct at the two standard parallels, because the standard parallels are the same on the globe as on the cone. The scale then decreases (contracts) between the standard parallels, reaching the minimum value at the parallel of the origin, and increases (expands) outside the parallels. The longitudes on the globe are projected into Euclidean straight lines on the cone. At the parallel of origin, Earth convergency is equal to chart convergency: The angle of two given longitudes on the Earth-globe is the same here as that of the two projections of longitude on the cone. Note: Same scale = Standard Parallels Same convergency = Parallel of Origin

learning.explanation: Layer Tinting (also called hypsometric tint) is a method of showing relief of maps and charts by colouring different levels in different shades. A different colour is used for ground in different elevation bands. The basic shades are those of brown. The darker the shade, the higher is the height above sea level. The altitudes represented by each tint are indicated on the maps and charts. For example, land between mean sea level and 250 feet may be coloured white, between 250 feet and 500 feet light yellow, and so on. A key to colour code is given in the margin of the map. ICAO Annex 4 Definitions Hypsometric tints. A succession of shades or colour gradations used to depict ranges of elevation.

content.question: Crossing the North Atlantic on an eastbound track from position X(52ºN, 040ºW) to position Y(53ºN, 030ºW), the average true track is 080º. On a Lambert chart with standard parallels at 75ºN and 30ºN, the direction of the straight line at position…

key_points: For a Lambert chart the following convergency formula is applied: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Parallel of Origin
Average true track 080o is the track measured exactly in the middle point between X and Y, while crossing the 35oW meridian
Parallel of origin is the mean latitude between the two standard parallels: (75o N + 30o N) / 2 = 52
learning.explanation: For a Lambert chart the following convergency formula is applied: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Parallel of Origin. Average true track 080o is the track measured exactly in the middle point between X and Y, while crossing the 35oW meridian. Parallel of origin is the mean latitude between the two standard parallels: (75o N + 30o N) / 2 = 52.5o N. Applying the rule, "SAME HEMISPHERES - SUBTRACT", the Change of Longitude between X and Y is: 40o W - 30o W = 10o. Thus, Convergency = 10o x sin 52,5o = 7.9o. That means that the true track from X to Y position changes by 7.9o, so until the middle point, it changes by: 7.9o/2 = 4o rounded. Bear in mind that both X and Y lie on the Northern hemisphere, where meridians converge inwards towards the North Pole and as we travel eastwards and at a higher latitude, the true track increases. So, true track will be lower at X than in the middle point and consequently lower in the middle point than at Y. The direction at position X is: 080o - 4o = 76o and The direction at position Y is: 080o + 4o = 84o. Therefore, the correct answer is that the direction of the straight line at position X is 076º.

content.question: On a Polar Stereographic projection the chart convergency between two positions depends on the:

options.A: difference in longitude and the mean latitude of the two positions.
options.B: difference in latitude of the two positions.
options.C: difference in longitude of the two positions.
options.D: difference in latitude and the mean longitude of the two positions.

key_points: Polar Stereographic Chart Convergence The meridians converge at the pole at exactly the same rate as they do on the Earth’s surface
Therefore, on the projection the convergency remains the same, whereas on Earth it decreases away from the Pole
This gives the Polar stereographic chart a convergency factor, or ‘n’, of 1
learning.explanation: Polar Stereographic Chart Convergence The meridians converge at the pole at exactly the same rate as they do on the Earth’s surface. Therefore, on the projection the convergency remains the same, whereas on Earth it decreases away from the Pole. This gives the Polar stereographic chart a convergency factor, or ‘n’, of 1. The chart convergence is always exactly equal to the change of longitude between 2 points, whatever the latitude. Chart convergence is constant all over the chart.

content.question: You are flying on a magnetic heading (MH) of 185° and your location is in the northern hemisphere. The relative bearing of an NDB is indicated on your relative bearing indicator as 065°. What true bearing should be plotted from the beacon to the aircraft on a Lambert chart if the variation at the aircraft is 6°E and the variation at the station is 4°E and the chart convergence between the aircraft and the NDB is 8°?

key_points: Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading
Add relative bearing to true heading in order to get true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360
Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station
learning.explanation: Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to get true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading - 180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: Bearings measured at ground station (VOR, VDF) - variation at ground station Bearings measured at aircraft (NDB/ADF, AWR) - variation at aircraft True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 191º 6ºE 185º The exercise is asking us for a true bearing from the beacon to the aircraft (QTE): QUJ= 65º + 191º = 256º QTE = 65º + 191º - 180º = 76º Unlike the Mercator chart where chart convergence is zero, in a Lambert conformal chart the meridians merge with each other at the poles. To plot a bearing in a Lambert chart we must apply the chart convergence, because there is chart convergence between the meridians where the bearing is measured (aircraft) and from it will be plotted (NDB). If you plot the true bearing of the NDB from the aircraft 256º, in a Lambert char the plot will be correct. The problem is when you need to plot the reciprocal from the meridian of the NDB, the line will not pass through the aircraft position, If the angle of 076º is measured from a line that is parallel to the aircraft meridian drawn to the NDB, the position line will pass trough the aircraft like in figure (b). When drawing the line parallel to the aircraft’s meridian, chart convergence as been automatically allowed. Figure (b) show as that the reciprocal of of 256º will have an angular value lower than 076º, that difference will be the chart convergence of 8º. Bearing to be plotted from the NDB to the aircraft = 076º - 8º = 068º NOTE: The drawing the bearings are 270º and 090º that will correspond to 256º and 076º.

Second Step: Derive the rhumb line bearing from the aircraft to the station by applying the conversion angle. learning.explanation: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i.e. the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth. On a Lamberts Conformal Conical chart this is the point where the external cone forms the tangent and this parallel of latitude is known as the Parallel of Origin. In effect, the Lamberts chart is constructed from a secant cone which is placed inside the Earth - as such it intersects the Earth surface at two points, known as Standard Parallels. The Scale in Lambert conformal chart is only correct along the standard parallels. Part of the chart (outside the Standard Parallels) is outside the Earth and part (inside the Standard Parallels) is inside the Earth. The Parallel of Origin (from the outer cone) is mathematically projected onto this inner cone and is located slightly poleward of the mid-point of the Standard Parallels; however, for simplicity we assume the Parallel of Origin is half-way between the Standard Parallels, i.e. the average of the Standard Parallels. The Parallel of Origin determines the Convergence Factor for the whole chart and is equal to the Sine of this latitude, i.e. the Sine of the Parallel of Origin.

Given:
Lambert conformal conical projection, scale 1: 1 234 000.
Standard parallels 36°N and 60°N.. A 53°N, 010°W, B 53°N, 020°W
The distance on the map between position A and position B measured along the rhumb line:

key_points: PROPERTIES OF A LAMBERT CHART Scale Correct on the standard parallels
Contracted within the standard parallels
Expanded outside standard parallels
learning.explanation: PROPERTIES OF A LAMBERT CHART Scale Correct on the standard parallels. Contracted within the standard parallels. Expanded outside standard parallels. The chart scale depicts the relationship between the length represented on the chart and the actual distance on planet Earth (departure): Chart Scale = Chart length / Earth distance The provided coordinates indicate that both positions are situated on the 53°N parallel of latitude, forming a rhumb line. To calculate the Earth distance between these points along the 53°N parallel (rhumb line), the departure can be used: Departure = Change of longitude (minutes) x 60 x cos (latitude) Departure = 10 x 60 x cos (53º) = 361.09 NM or 361.09 x 1.852 x 100 000 cm The scale of the Lambert chart at latitude 53°N is 1:1 234 000 (1 cm on the chart equals 1 234 000 cm on the Earth). Therefore, we can determine the Earth distance as follows: A distance of 1 cm on the chart corresponds to a distance of 1 234 000 cm on Earth. A distance of x cm on the chart represents a distance of 361.09 x 1.852 x 100 000 cm on the Earth. x = (361.09 x 1.852 x 100 000) ÷ 1 234 000 x = 54.19 cm The scale is contracted within the standard parallels, therefore the scale at 53°N latitude is smaller than the Lambert chart's scale (1:1 234 000), meaning the scale at 53°N has a denominator greater than 1 234 000. Consequently, the Earth distance will be represented on the chart by a distance less than 54.19 cm.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which one of the figures most accurately represents the great circle route from A to B on a Polar Stereographic chart?

key_points: Polar Stereographic chart projection assumes that a flat plane touches at the Pole, with the origin of the projection at the opposite pole
The tangential point of a Polar Stereographic chart is the pole

The Meridians are straight lines radiating from the pole, cutting the parallels of latitude at right angles and the Parallels of latitude are concentric circles and their distance apart increases away from the pole
learning.explanation: Polar Stereographic chart projection assumes that a flat plane touches at the Pole, with the origin of the projection at the opposite pole. The tangential point of a Polar Stereographic chart is the pole. The Meridians are straight lines radiating from the pole, cutting the parallels of latitude at right angles and the Parallels of latitude are concentric circles and their distance apart increases away from the pole. On a Polar Stereographic chart, the great circles at the tangential point would be straight lines, but since it is a point, you cannot draw a great circle there. The great circles that cut through the pole (tangential point) will also be straight lines, these are the meridians. Elsewhere, the great circles will actually be slightly curved concave to the pole on the Polar side, but near the pole can be assumed to be straight lines. Therefore, for the great circles on a Polar Stereographic chart: "The higher their latitude (the closer to the Pole), The less their curvature".

Initially, we must use the chart to calculate the magnetic variation, and by interpolating for the point of 74ºN, 15ºE between isogonals of 5ºE and 10ºE, we get a magnetic variation of 7ºE. Using the rhyme, "Variation West, Magnetic Best Variation East, Magnetic Least", we can see that the initial great circle track (GCT) from the aircraft's position is 064º(T). Then by using either a DIDI diagram or the diagram shown above, we can calculate the effect of convergency on the great circle track. Convergency = Change of longitude x sin(mean latitude) The mean latitude is approximately 74º15'. The change of longitude is very close to 4º, so we can use that value. Convergency = 4 x sin(74º15') = 3.85º, for ease of calculations we can call this 4º convergency. This means that the final great circle track (GCT) from the aircraft's position to the "BJO" NDB is 4º greater (the direction of change is found by using the chart above or a DIDI diagram) than the initial GCT, so the final GCT is 068º(T). This means the initial GCT for the opposite track (from the NDB to the aircraft) is just the inverse (+/- 180º) of 068º, and the answer is therefore 248º(T).

While flying on a magnetic heading of 185° (M) in the northern hemisphere, an aircraft measures the relative bearing of ‘ONO’ NDB on an RBI Relative Bearing Indicator as 065°R. Given the following information, what bearing should be plotted from the beacon to the aircraft on a Lambert chart?
Variation at the aircraft: 6°E
Variation at the station: 4°E
Chart convergence between the aircraft and the NDB: 8°

key_points: Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading

Bearings measured at ground station (VOR, VDF) - variation at ground station Bearings measured at aircraft (NDB/ADF, AWR) - variation at aircraft True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 191° 6°E 185° Add relative bearing to true heading in order to get true bearing TO the station
If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360
learning.explanation: Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Bearings measured at ground station (VOR, VDF) - variation at ground station Bearings measured at aircraft (NDB/ADF, AWR) - variation at aircraft True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 191° 6°E 185° Add relative bearing to true heading in order to get true bearing TO the station. If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading - 180° The exercise is asking us for a true bearing from the beacon to the aircraft (QTE): QUJ= 65° + 191° = 256° QTE = 65° + 191° - 180° = 76° Now to apply the convergency. The chart convergence here means that we can not just plot the reciprocal heading from an NDB, as this would give us a false position, as We have to account for the 8° convergency, and to work out how to do this, the best way is often to use a diagram like the one above, and note that the red angle is smaller at the NDB than the same angle would be at the aircraft, so therefore the red angle is 8° smaller than the reciprocal bearing of 076°. This can also be done without drawing if you are adept at using the DIID method, but be careful, that way is much easier to make a mistake. True bearing to be plotted from the NDB to the aircraft = 076° - 8° = 068°

Conversion angle = ½ Convergency Difference in Longitude = 170º Convergency is therefore: 170º x sin 60º = 147º The conversion angle is then: 147º : 2 = 74º "A" and "B" lie on the same latitude, therefore, rhumb line direction will be 90º when flying east and 270º when flying west

key_points: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i
e
the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth
learning.explanation: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i.e. the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth. On a Lamberts Conformal Conical chart this is the point where the external cone forms the tangent and this parallel of latitude is known as the Parallel of Origin. In effect, the Lamberts chart is constructed from a secant cone which is placed inside the Earth - as such it intersects the Earth surface at two points, known as Standard Parallels. Part of the chart (outside the Standard Parallels) is outside the Earth and part (inside the Standard Parallels) is inside the Earth. The Parallel of Origin (from the outer cone) is mathematically projected onto this inner cone and is located slightly poleward of the mid-point of the Standard Parallels; however, for simplicity we assume the Parallel of Origin is half-way between the Standard Parallels, i.e. the average of the Standard Parallels. The Parallel of Origin determines the Convergence Factor for the whole chart and is equal to the Sine of this latitude, i.e. the Sine of the Parallel of Origin. The Convergence Factor is also known (on a Lamberts Chart) as the 'Constant of the Cone' or simply 'n'. The equation for convergency is: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Convergence Factor Correct Answer: depends on the latitude of the parallel of origin and on difference n longitude f two positions.

Convergency is given by the formula: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Mean Latitude. Considering the above, we can say that the average great circle true track and the rhumb line true track will be approximately the same where convergency (thus, conversion angle) is the least.
