content.question: In a Lambert chart with standard parallels at 37°N and 65°N, concerning the straight line depicted on the map connecting points A (N49° W030°) and B (N48° W040°), which statement is accurate?

options.A: Rhumb line is to the north, the great circle is to the south.
options.B: Great circle and rhumb line are to the north.
options.C: Great circle and rhumb line are to the south.
options.D: Great circle is to the north, the rhumb line is to the south.

key_points: On a Lambert chart, the characteristics of Great Circles and Rhumb Lines are as follows: For Great Circles: Meridians are depicted as straight lines
Near the parallel of origin, they appear nearly straight
At any other latitude, Great Circle tracks take on a curved shape that is concave towards the parallel of origin
learning.explanation: On a Lambert chart, the characteristics of Great Circles and Rhumb Lines are as follows: For Great Circles: Meridians are depicted as straight lines. Near the parallel of origin, they appear nearly straight. At any other latitude, Great Circle tracks take on a curved shape that is concave towards the parallel of origin. For Rhumb Lines: Meridians are shown as straight lines. All other Rhumb Lines are concave toward the pole. This curvature is particularly noticeable in parallels of latitude. In the context of this Lambert chart, the standard parallels are 65ºN and 37ºN. The Parallel of Origin falls between these standard parallels, approximately at 51ºN. Consequently, when drawing a straight-line track from 49ºN 030ºW to 48ºN 040ºW, this track will be positioned south of the Parallel of Origin. The Great Circle track between these points will exhibit concavity toward the Parallel of Origin, which means it will be positioned south of the straight-line track. Similarly, the Rhumb Line Track will also show concavity towards the nearer pole and will lie on the equatorial side of the Great Circle Track. Therefore, it will be situated to the south of the Great Circle Track.

An aircraft is at position 53°N, 006°W and has a landmark at position 52°47’N, 004°45’W, with a relative bearing of 060°. Given:

Deviation = 2°E
What is the true bearing of the position line to be plotted from the landmark to the aircraft on a Lambert chart with standard parallels at 37°N and 65°N?

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Compass Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 037º 16ºW 053º 2ºE 051º Aircraft’s True Track from the feature, QTE = 060º + 037º + 180º = 277º (T) Unlike the Mercator chart where chart convergence is zero, in a Lambert conformal chart the meridians merge with each other at the poles. To plot a bearing in a Lambert chart we must apply the chart convergence, because there is chart convergence between the meridians where the bearing is measured (aircraft) and from it will be plotted (NDB). If you plot the true bearing of the NDB from the aircraft 097º, in a Lambert char the plot will be correct. The problem is when you need to plot the reciprocal from the meridian of the NDB, the line will not pass through the aircraft position. When drawing the line parallel to the aircraft’s meridian, chart convergence as been automatically allowed. Chart convergence = ch.long × sin parallel of origin Chart convergence = (006º00’- 004º45’) x sin ((65+37)/2) = 1º The reciprocal of 097º will have an angular value higher than 277º, that difference will be the chart convergence of 1º If the angle of 278º is measured from a line that is parallel to the aircraft meridian drawn to the NDB, the position line will pass trough the aircraft. Bearing to be plotted from the NDB to the aircraft = 277º + 1º = 278º

learning.explanation: The Groundspeed can be calculated when the Earth (ground) distance covered is known in a given flight time: GS = Earth distance / Flight time. The flight time between Waypoint 1 and Waypoint 2 is: 10:49 UTC - 10:34 UTC = 15 min or 0.25 hr. The chart distance between Waypoint 1 and Waypoint 2 is 13.8 cm. content.question: A Lambert conformal conic chart, whose standard parallels 54°N and 59°N is used for navigation. Straight line from A (53°N, 165°E) to B (58°N, 145°E) is drawn on the chart. key_points: In a Lambert conformal conic chart, a great circle at the parallel of origin appears almost as a straight line

Chart convergence, which represents the angle of inclination between meridians on the chart (or the change in direction of a straight line) between two longitudes, remains constant across the entire chart

The formula for chart convergence in a Lambert conformal conic chart is given by: Chart convergence = change in longitude × sin (parallel of origin) Now, let's determine the parallel of origin using the standard parallels of 54ºN and 59ºN: Parallel of Origin = (54ºN + 59ºN) / 2 = 56
learning.explanation: In a Lambert conformal conic chart, a great circle at the parallel of origin appears almost as a straight line. Chart convergence, which represents the angle of inclination between meridians on the chart (or the change in direction of a straight line) between two longitudes, remains constant across the entire chart. The formula for chart convergence in a Lambert conformal conic chart is given by: Chart convergence = change in longitude × sin (parallel of origin) Now, let's determine the parallel of origin using the standard parallels of 54ºN and 59ºN: Parallel of Origin = (54ºN + 59ºN) / 2 = 56.5ºN Substituting this into the chart convergence formula: Chart convergence = change in longitude × sin (56.5ºN) Chart convergence = 20º × 0.834 ≈ 17º Referring to the D-I-I-D scheme and flying westerly in the Northern Hemisphere, the angular value of the GCT (Great Circle Track) will decrease: GCT at B < GCT at A GCT at B = GCT at A - Chart convergence GCT at B = 301º - 17º GCT at B = 284º T

learning.explanation: For a Lambert conformal conic projection chart the following convergency formula is applied: Convergency = Change of Longitude x Sin Parallel of Origin (or Constant of cone). content.question: The scale of a Lambert conformal conic chart is the:

options.A: mean scale between pole and equator
options.C: mean scale between the parallels of the secant cone

key_points: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i
e
the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth
learning.explanation: Convergency on charts (within this syllabus) is determined by the Origin of the chart, i.e. the point where the chart forms a tangent with the surface of the Earth. On a Lamberts Conformal Conical chart this is the point where the external cone forms the tangent and this parallel of latitude is known as the Parallel of Origin. In effect, the Lamberts chart is constructed from a secant cone which is placed inside the Earth - as such it intersects the Earth surface at two points, known as Standard Parallels. The Scale in Lambert conformal chart is only correct along the standard parallels. Part of the chart (outside the Standard Parallels) is outside the Earth and part (inside the Standard Parallels) is inside the Earth. The Parallel of Origin (from the outer cone) is mathematically projected onto this inner cone and is located slightly poleward of the mid-point of the Standard Parallels; however, for simplicity we assume the Parallel of Origin is half-way between the Standard Parallels, i.e. the average of the Standard Parallels. The Parallel of Origin determines the Convergence Factor for the whole chart and is equal to the Sine of this latitude, i.e. the Sine of the Parallel of Origin.

content.question: Which statement is correct about large/small scale maps?

options.A: A small scale map shows more area represented with more detail.
options.B: A large scale map shows more area represented with less detail.
options.C: A large scale map shows more area represented with more detail.
options.D: A small scale map shows more area represented and less detail.

key_points: LARGE AND SMALL SCALE MAPS Maps are described as either large scale or small scale
Large scale maps show a smaller amount of area with a greater amount of detail
The geographic extent shown on a large scale map is small
learning.explanation: LARGE AND SMALL SCALE MAPS Maps are described as either large scale or small scale. Large scale maps show a smaller amount of area with a greater amount of detail. The geographic extent shown on a large scale map is small. A large scaled map expressed as a representative scale would have a smaller number to the right of the ratio (for example, 1 : 1 000). Small scale maps show a larger geographic area with few details on them. The RF scale of a small scale map would have a much larger number to the right of the colon such as 1 : 1 000 000.
